{{refimprove|date=December 2013}} {{Year nav topic5|1679|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1679'''.
==Events== *June – [[Nathaniel Lee]]'s play ''The Massacre at Paris'' (about the [[St. Bartholomew's Day massacre]] of 1572, as was [[Christopher Marlowe]]'s play of the same title) is suppressed by King [[Charles II of England]] as anti-French, the French being English allies at this time. *[[December 18]] – Rose Alley ambuscade: [[John Dryden]] is set upon by three assailants in London, thought to have been instigated by the [[John Wilmot, 2nd Earl of Rochester]] in retaliation for an attack on "want of wit" in his poetry in ''The Essay on Satire'' (nominally by Dryden's patron, the poet [[John Sheffield, 1st Duke of Buckingham and Normanby|John Sheffield, Earl of Musgrave]], but probably with input from Dryden).<ref>{{cite book|first1=John|last1=Sutherland|authorlink1=John Sutherland (author)|first2=Stephen|last2=Fender|title=Love, Sex, Death & Words: surprising tales from a year in literature|location=London|publisher=Icon Books|year=2011|isbn=978-184831-247-0|chapter=18 December – Dryden mugged|pages=479-80}}</ref> *[[John Locke]] returns to England from France. *[[Étienne Baluze]] becomes almoner to King [[Louis XIV of France]]. *[[Thomas Otway]] returns to England from military service in the Netherlands. *[[Pu Songling]] probably compiles most of his ''[[Strange Stories from a Chinese Studio]]''.
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Charles Blount (deist)|Charles Blount]] – ''Anima Mundi'' *[[Jean de La Fontaine]] – ''The Fables of Bidpai''
===Drama=== *[[Beaumont and Fletcher]] – ''Fifty Comedies and Tragedies'', the [[Beaumont and Fletcher folios#The second folio, 1679|second folio]] *[[Aphra Behn]] **''The Feigned Courtesans'' **''The Young King'' *[[John Crowne]] – ''The Ambitious Statesman, or the Loyal Favourite'' *[[John Dryden]] **''Oedipus'' **''Troilus and Cressida, or Truth Found Too Late'' (adapted from [[Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Troilus and Cressida]]'') *[[Nathaniel Lee]] **''Caesar Borgia'' **''The Massacre at Paris'' *[[Thomas Otway]] – ''The History and Fall of Caius Marius'' *[[Jacques Pradon]] – ''La Troade'' *[[Thomas Shadwell]] **''A True Widow'' **''The Woman Captain''
===Poetry=== *"Ephelia" ([[Mary Stewart, Duchess of Richmond|Mary Villiers]]?) – ''Female Poems...by Ephelia''
==Births== *[[January 24]] – [[Christian Wolff (philosopher)|Christian Wolff]], German philosopher (died [[1745 in literature|1745]]) *[[August 16]] – [[Catherine Trotter Cockburn]], English novelist, dramatist and philosopher (died [[1749 in literature|1749]]) *[[September 11]] – [[Thomas Parnell]], Irish poet and cleric (died [[1718 in literature|1718]]) *[[September 24]] – [[Eugenio Gerardo Lobo]], Spanish poet and soldier (died [[1750 in literature|1750]]) *[[September 26]] – [[Johann Gottlob Carpzov]], German Biblical scholar (died [[1767 in literature|1767]]) *[[October 26]] – [[Heinrich Jacob Bashuysen]], German printer (died c. 1750) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Charles Johnson (writer)|Charles Johnson]], English dramatist and poet (died [[1748 in literature|1748]]) **[[Robert Wodrow]], Scottish historian (died [[1734 in literature|1734]]) *''Probable year of birth'' – [[Penelope Aubin]], English novelist and translator (died c. 1731)
==Deaths== *[[January 11]] – [[Joannes Lucius]], Dalmatian historian (born [[1604 in literature|1604]]) *[[February 5]] – [[Joost van den Vondel]], Dutch dramatist (born [[1587 in literature|1587]]) *[[April 4]] – [[Christian Hoffmann von Hoffmannswaldau]], German poet (born [[1616 in literature|1616]]) *[[June 7]] – [[Alice Curwen]], English autobiographer and Quaker (born c. 1619) *[[August 27]] – [[Jonas Moore]], English mathematician and surveyor (born [[1617 in literature|1617]]) *[[October 12]] – [[William Gurnall]], English writer and cleric (born [[1617 in literature|1617]]) *[[October 26]] – [[Roger Boyle, 1st Earl of Orrery]] Irish dramatist and soldier (born [[1621 in literature|1621]]) *[[December 4]] – [[Thomas Hobbes]], English philosopher (born [[1588 in literature|1588]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Jacob Alting]], Dutch philologist and theologian (born [[1618 in literature|1618]]) **[[Johann Michael Vansleb]], German theologian and linguist (born [[1635 in literature|1635]])
==In literature== *[[Walter Scott]]'s novel ''[[Old Mortality]]'' ([[1816 in literature|1816]]) opens in this year.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1679 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 17th century in literature]]

{{Year nav topic5|1964|film|television|radio }} {{Yearsinfilm}}<!-- SIDEBAR NAV-BOX --> The year '''1964 in film''' involved some significant events, including two highly successful musical films, ''[[My Fair Lady (film)|My Fair Lady]]'' and ''[[Mary Poppins (film)|Mary Poppins]]''.
==Events== * March 6 – [[Elvis Presley]]'s 14th motion picture, ''[[Kissin' Cousins]]'', is released to theaters. * July 6 – ''[[A Hard Day's Night (film)|A Hard Day's Night]]'', the first [[The Beatles|Beatles]] film, premieres. * October – In ''[[Photoplay]]'' magazine, [[Hedda Hopper]] announces that [[Sophia Loren]] and [[Paul Newman]] will star in the film version of [[Arthur Miller]]'s play ''After the Fall'', with Loren in the role that was written about [[Marilyn Monroe]]. The film is never made.

==Awards== '''[[37th Academy Awards|Academy Awards]]:'''
:[[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]]: '''''[[My Fair Lady (film)|My Fair Lady]]''''' – Warner Bros. :[[Academy Award for Directing|Best Director]]: '''[[George Cukor]]''' – ''My Fair Lady'' :[[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]]: '''[[Rex Harrison]]''' – ''My Fair Lady'' :[[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]]: '''[[Julie Andrews]]''' – ''[[Mary Poppins (film)|Mary Poppins]]'' :[[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]]: '''[[Peter Ustinov]]''' – ''[[Topkapi (film)|Topkapi]]'' :[[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]]: '''[[Lila Kedrova]]''' – ''[[Zorba the Greek]]'' :[[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]]: '''''[[Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow (film)|Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow]]''''' (''Ieri, oggi, domani''), directed by [[Vittorio De Sica]], Italy
'''[[22nd Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards]]:'''
:<u>'''Drama:'''</u> :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Drama|Best Picture]]: '''''[[Becket (1964 film)|Becket]]''''' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama|Best Actor]]: '''[[Peter O'Toole]]''' – ''Becket'' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama|Best Actress]]: '''[[Anne Bancroft]]''' – ''[[The Pumpkin Eater]]'' :Best Supporting Actress: '''[[Agnes Moorehead]]''' – ''[[Hush… Hush, Sweet Charlotte]]'' :Best Supporting Actor: '''[[Edmund O'Brien]]''' – ''[[Seven Days in May]]''
:<u>'''Musical or comedy:'''</u> :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy|Best Picture]]: '''''My Fair Lady''''' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actor]]: '''Rex Harrison''' – ''My Fair Lady'' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actress]]: '''Julie Andrews''' – ''Mary Poppins''
:<u>'''Other'''</u> :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Director – Motion Picture|Best Director]]: '''George Cukor''' – ''My Fair Lady''
'''[[Palme d'Or]] (Cannes Film Festival):''' :'''''[[Les Parapluies de Cherbourg]]''''' (''The Umbrellas of Cherbourg''), directed by [[Jacques Demy]], France
'''[[Golden Lion]] (Venice Film Festival):''' :'''''[[Il deserto rosso]]''''' (''The Red Desert''), directed by [[Michelangelo Antonioni]], Italy
'''[[Berlin Film Festival|Golden Bear]] (Berlin Film Festival):''' :'''''[[Susuz Yaz]]''''' (''Dry Summer''), directed by [[Metin Erksan|Ismail Metin]], Turkey

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Lotto, pala dell'Alabarda 01.jpg | title=Altarpiece of the Halberd | artist=Lorenzo Lotto | year=c. 1539 | medium=Oil on canvas | height_metric=294 | width_metric=216 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in |city=Ancona | museum=Pinacoteca civica Francesco Podesti }} The '''Altarpiece of the Halberd''' is a painting from around 1539 by the [[Italy|Italian]] [[High Renaissance]] painter [[Lorenzo Lotto]]. It is housed in the [[Pinacoteca civica Francesco Podesti]] of [[Ancona]], central Italy.
==History==
The work was seen by the art biographer [[Giorgio Vasari]] in the church of [[Sant'Agostino, Ancona|Sant'Agostino]] in Ancona, where Lotto had fled in reply to the hostility received in Venice. It was later moved to the church of [[Santa Maria della Piazza]] and, after other locations, the current one.
The painting dates to a few years after the [[coup]] by which Ancona had been restored to the [[Papal States]]. The resistance had been brutally suppressed, many of the rebels having been beheaded by order of the papal legate. The upside-down [[halberd]] has been thus interpreted as a symbol of peace.
==Description== The monumental composition is taken directly from the tradition of [[Holy Conversation]]s in the [[Venetian school (art)|Venetian School]], inaugurated by [[Antonello da Messina]]'s [[San Cassiano Altarpiece]]. It shows the Madonna and Child on a high throne, with two angels holding the crown (a 15th-century [[Flemish painting]] element also in use in Italy). In the lower part are four saints: Stephen, John the Evangelist, [[Simon the Zealot]] and [[St. Lawrence|Lawrence]]. Simon is holding the [[halberd]] which gives its name to the altarpiece. At the sides of the throne, between columns and draperies, are two sections of sky with clouds.
Like in other Lotto's works, the symmetry is broken by the variety of postures and gestures; the work is general characterized by a certain archaic style, explainable by the relatively provincial commissioners and the late stage of his career.
==Sources== *{{cite book|title=Lotto|first=Carlo|last=Pirovano|publisher=Electa|location=Milan|year=2002}}
[[Category:1539 paintings]] [[Category:Lotto Madonnas]] [[Category:Paintings of Saint Stephen]] [[Category:Paintings in Marche]] [[Category:Ancona]] [[Category:Altarpieces]] [[Category:Angels in art]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE: Architecture of ''Star Wars'' }} [[Image:Star Wars in Tunisia.jpg|thumb|200px|''Star Wars'' filming location in Tunisia]] '''Architecture in ''Star Wars''''' includes the cities, buildings, ships, and other structures of the fictional ''[[Star Wars]]'' [[fictional universe|universe]] as described and depicted in books, movies, comics, and cartoons. ''[[Architects Journal]]'' ranked the top 10, including the [[Death Star]] and the [[Jedi Temple]].<ref name="architecture">James Pallister [http://www.architectsjournal.co.uk/story.aspx?storyCode=5203477 Top 10: The Architecture of Star Wars (pt II)] 15 June 2009 Architects Journal (UK)</ref>
Comparing the urban and natural environments pictured in ''Star Wars'', Mark Lamster wrote that the cities are places of danger and corruption, while the forces of good find sanctuary in the natural world.<ref name="ambivalent">Mark Lamster "Evil foes build ever-more-elaborate urban monstrosities- machines not for living but killing, and killing on a grand scale" [https://books.google.com/books?id=Dxis1i4jxVwC&pg=PA234 Architecture and film] Star Wars and the City page 6</ref> He also describes the "retro-[[futurist]]" cities in the series as being in between those extremes and places of "great beauty but dubious moral character." He attributes the ambivalence towards urbanity to series creator [[George Lucas]]' own feelings about cities and urban environments.<ref name="ambivalent"/>
The settings of the movie have generally been praised, but one author took exception to the "anachronistic period architecture and statuary" of ''[[Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace]]'', saying it improperly associated [[third world]] buildings with conceptions of innocence and the primitive in a way that was discriminatory and demeaning.<ref name="hives"/>
==Planet settings== [[Luke Skywalker]] is first seen in ''[[Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope]]'' living with his adoptive parents in a "complex of caves and domed structures" on [[Tatooine]], filmed in the [[Tunisia]]n desert town of [[Matmata, Tunisia|Matmata]].<ref name="hives">Mark Lamster [https://books.google.com/books?id=Dxis1i4jxVwC&pg=PA234&dq=star+wars+architecture#v=onepage&q=star%20wars%20architecture&f=false Architecture and film] Wretched Hives: George Lucas and the Ambivalent Architecture of Star Wars page 234</ref> The end of the first movie was shot in the [[Guatemala]]n [[rain forest]] where a celebration with rebel allies takes place in a caved area (a scene said to be borrowed from [[Leni Riefenstahl]]'s 1935 [[Nazi]] [[propaganda film]] ''[[Triumph of the Will]]''<ref name="hives"/>). The exotic locales provide scenery that is unfamiliar to "all but a few experts in non-western architecture", providing the films with fantastic settings that could still be believable.<ref name="hives"/>
==Urban planning== Three architecture and planning students noted that the "latest" (1999) ''Star Wars'' movie ''(The Phantom Menace)'' offered "a variety of urban development options" in a ''[[San Diego Union-Tribune]]'' story headlined "How would you like to live on a Star Wars' world?"<ref name="cosmic">Roger M. Showley "The latest "Star Wars" movie offers a variety of urban development options according to three architecture and planning students who previewed the film; from left, [Tim Belzman], San Diego State University; Bruce Fallown, Newschool of Architecture; and [David Sin], Woodbury University School of Architecture." [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sandiego/access/74622433.html?dids=74622433:74622433&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+30%2C+1999&author=Roger+M.+Showley&pub=The+San+Diego+Union+-+Tribune&desc=Cosmic+communities+%7C+How+would+you+like+to+live+on+a+%60Star+Wars'+world%3F&pqatl=google Cosmic communities]; How would you like to live on a `Star Wars' world? May 30, 1999 page H.1 San Diego Union-Tribune</ref> The article included illustrations of [[Coruscant]] ("completely covered by development" and "surrounded by mile-high skyscrapers"), including views from the [[Jedi]] Council building, and the city of ''Theed'' (inspired by [[Palace of Caserta|an 18th-century palace]] near [[Naples|Naples, Italy]]).<ref name="cosmic"/> On Coruscant, "development extends miles below the surface of the city and up into the clouds."<ref name="cosmic"/>
The "urban future" has also been depicted in ''[[Blade Runner]]'' where "the setting is a grimy, crime-ridden [[Los Angeles]] in the 21st century".<ref name="cosmic"/> The architecture of ''Star Wars'' may also have been influenced by [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]''.<ref name="hives"/> The designs continued Lucas' work from his first feature film, ''[[THX 1138]]'', which featured a [[claustrophobia|claustrophobic]], [[George Orwell|Orwellian]] "subteranean world of black-and-white spaces" where the population is subdued with drugs and kept under constant surveillance.<ref name="hives"/>
===Jedi Temple=== ''[[Architects' Journal]]'' rated the '''Jedi Temple''' (located in the capital planet of ''[[Coruscant]]'') third on its top-ten architecture of ''Star Wars'' list behind the second [[Death Star]] and [[Jabba the Hutt’s palace]] on [[Tatooine]], and ahead of Coruscant, capital city of the Old Republic.<ref name="architecture" /> The temple is described in the article as adapting "the robust typology of Mayan temples, with durasteel cladding specified for the external stone walls for improved defensive strength" and said to be a [[ziggurat]] that "is built above a Force-nexus and has ample room for training facilities, accommodation and the Jedi Archive."<ref name="architecture"/> The temple has five towers, the tallest is Tranquillity Spire, that are stylistically similar to the [[minaret]]s surrounding the [[Hagia Sophia]] in [[Istanbul]].<ref name="architecture"/> ''[[Star Wars Insider]]'' listed it as the one hundredth greatest thing about ''Star Wars'' in its one hundredth issue special.
==Ships== The [[battle cruiser]]s featured in ''Star Wars'' have been described as examples of "[[Suprematist]] architecture".<ref>Simon Ings [https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg17022875.500-falling-star.html Falling star] 21 April 2001 ''New Scientist''</ref>
==Real world buildings that mirror ''Star Wars''== The [[San Francisco Federal Building]] designed by [[Thom Mayne]] has been compared to the [[Jawa (Star Wars)|Jawa]] [[Sandcrawler]] featured in ''[[Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope]]''.<ref>Joshua Glenn [http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/ideas/brainiac/2007/04/architecture_im.html Architecture imitates art?] April 25, 2007 Boston Globe</ref> The [[ING House|ING headquarters]] building (in [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]]) has been described as looking like something out of ''Star Wars'' that could "move forward on its legs".<ref>Philip Jodidio [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ut5V7tVWdJsC&pg=RA1-PT341&dq=star+wars+architecture#v=onepage&q=star%20wars%20architecture&f=false Architecture now! ]</ref> Conversely, the [[Trinity College, Dublin]], [[Trinity College Library|Long Room]] Library is thought to be the basis for the [[Jedi]] Academy Library in ''[[Star Wars: Episode II – Attack of the Clones]]''.<ref>[http://www.rte.ie/ten/2002/1111/starwars.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121231081314/http://www.rte.ie/ten/2002/1111/starwars.html |date=December 31, 2012 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.archiseek.com/ireland/news/2002/000238.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120102090635/http://www.archiseek.com/ireland/news/2002/000238.htm |date=January 2, 2012 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Jedi Academy]] *[[TIE fighter]] *[[Technology in Star Wars|Technology in ''Star Wars'']]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *Kippins, Jeffrey ''Star Wars III: The Battle at the Center of the Universe; Investigations in Architecture'' Eisenman Studios at the GSD 1983-1985 Ed. 1986 *{{citeweb|url=http://www.vogue.com/article/star-wars-architecture-soviet-union|title=What Star Wars Owes to Soviet Architecture|work=Liana Stanstien|publisher=vogue.com}}
{{Star Wars universe|state=collapsed}}

revision.comment: Updated based on the 2019 facts and figures.
revision.text:
'''Art Dubai''' is a leading international art fair that takes place every March in Dubai. Founded in 2007, Art Dubai is the preeminent platform to see art from the Middle East, North Africa and South Asia. Each year, the fair features a globally diverse lineup of over 90 galleries from more than 40 different countries, from household names to emerging art spaces<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://cdn.artdubai.ae/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/AD19_PR_Art-Dubai-Announces-Gallery-Line-Up-For-Its-2019-Edition_EN.pdf|title=Art Dubai|last=|first=|date=2018-11-07|work=Art Dubai|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref>, making it the world's most globally diverse art fair<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/culture/arts/a-complete-guide-to-art-dubai-1.2187870|title=A complete guide to Art Dubai|last=Review|first=Jyoti KalsiSpecial to Weekend|date=2018-03-14|work=GulfNews|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref>. Art Dubai is one of the major events on the international arts calendar, attracting over 28,000 visitors in 2018, including UAE-based, regional and international collectors, curators, patrons and nearly 100 visiting museums and institutions. Alongside its gallery halls, Art Dubai’s extensive programming includes commissioned artists’ and curators’ projects, residencies, education initiatives and the Global Art Forum<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.artdubai.ae/programming/|title=PROGRAMMING - Art Dubai|last=Dubai|first=Art|work=Art Dubai|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en-US}}</ref>.
Art Dubai is held under the patronage of His Highness Sheikh [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]]'','' Vice President and Prime Minister of the UAE and Ruler of [[Dubai]].
The 13th edition of Art Dubai will take place between March 20-23, 2019.
== Background == Art Dubai, originally called the Gulf Art Fair, was founded in 2007 by gallerist John Martin and former financier Benedict Floyd. It is part of the Art Dubai Group FZ LLC, which is part-owned by Middle East Fairs and the [[Dubai International Financial Centre|Dubai International Finance Center]] (DIFC).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://artasiapacific.com/Magazine/53/DIFCGulfArtFair|title=ArtAsiaPacific: Difc Gulf Art Fair|website=artasiapacific.com|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/6808648c-d960-11e5-a72f-1e7744c66818,Authorised=false.html?siteedition=intl&_i_location=http%253A%252F%252Fwww.ft.com%252Fcms%252Fs%252F0%252F6808648c-d960-11e5-a72f-1e7744c66818.html%253Fsiteedition%253Dintl&_i_referer=&classification=conditional_standard&iab=barrier-app#axzz4HIu4yZDt|title=UK banker who moved to Dubai and founded its leading art fair|last=Roux|first=Caroline|date=2016-03-11|newspaper=Financial Times|issn=0307-1766|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref>
Art Dubai is sponsored by [[Julius Baer Group|Julius Baer]] and [[Piaget SA|Piaget]]. [[BMW]] is the official car partner of Art Dubai and the Misk Art Institute is the exclusive partner of Art Dubai Modern<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.artdubai.ae/fair-partners/|title=FAIR PARTNERS - Art Dubai|last=Dubai|first=Art|work=Art Dubai|access-date=2018-04-09|language=en-US}}</ref>. [[Madinat Jumeirah]] is home to the event. [[Dubai Culture|The Dubai Culture & Arts Authority]] (DCAA) is a strategic partner of Art Dubai and supports the fair’s year-round non-for-profit education programme<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.artdubai.ae/global-art-forum/|title=GLOBAL ART FORUM 12: "I AM NOT A ROBOT" - Art Dubai|last=Dubai|first=Art|work=Art Dubai|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en-US}}</ref>.
== Galleries ==
=== Art Dubai Contemporary ===
Art Dubai’s gallery halls are split into four main sections: Contemporary, Modern, Bawwaba and Residents. Art Dubai Contemporary features commercial galleries operating on the primary market that have been established for at least two years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeoutdubai.com/art/events/40410-art-dubai-2016|title=Art Dubai 2016|website=Time Out Dubai|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref> Around 60 galleries are selected every year for Art Dubai Contemporary, from established galleries to younger art spaces from under-represented art capitals. Likewise, exhibited artists range from emerging practitioners to industry heavyweights.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/luxury/art/103384/art-dubai-highlights.html|title=Art Dubai: calm and collected-Telegraph|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref> The works presented at the fair cover painting, drawing, sculpture, installation, video, photography and performance. At the 2019 edition of Art Dubai, more than 90 galleries from over 40 countries will be featured, including newcomers from Cameroon and Colombia<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://cdn.artdubai.ae/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/AD19_PR_Art-Dubai-Announces-Gallery-Line-Up-For-Its-2019-Edition_EN.pdf|title=Art Dubai website|last=|first=|date=2018-11-07|work=Art Dubai|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref>.
Art Dubai Contemporary’s Selection Committee includes Co-Director of [[Victoria Miro Gallery]] (London/Venice) Glenn Scott Wright, Isabelle van den Eynde (Gallery Isabelle van den Eynde, Dubai), [[Andree Sfeir-Semler|Andrée Sfeir-Semler]] (Sfeir-Semler Gallery, Hamburg/Beirut) and Ursula Krinzinger (Galerie Krinzinger, Vienna).
=== Art Dubai Modern ===
Art Dubai Modern, established in 2014, is devoted to Modern art from the Middle East, Africa and South Asia. Each exhibitor presents a solo, two-person or multi-artist show, featuring works by Modern masters of the 20th century, with a focus on work produced between the 1940s and 1980s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/culture/arts/art-dubai-continues-its-cultural-journey-1.1687184|title=Art Dubai continues its cultural journey|last=Review|first=By Jyoti Kalsi, Special to Weekend|date=2016-03-09|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref> In 2019, Art Dubai Modern will move into one of the two main Contemporary halls, to allow for a better reading of the region's art history and contextualization of the Contemporary works on show.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cdn.artdubai.ae/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/AD19_PR_Art-Dubai-Announces-Gallery-Line-Up-For-Its-2019-Edition_EN.pdf|title=ART DUBAI ANNOUNCES GALLERY LINE-UP AND NEW STRUCTURE FOR ITS 2019 EDITION|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Art Dubai Modern’s Advisory Committee is composed of Dr Nada Shabout, professor of Art History and the Coordinator of the Contemporary Arab and Muslim Cultural Studies Initiative (CAMCSI) at the University of North Texas; Dr Iftikhar Dadi, associate professor in Cornell University’s Department of History of Art and Chair of its Department of Art; Catherine David, Deputy Director of Musée National d’Art Moderne, Paris; and Vali Mahlouji, curator, director of the Kaveh Golestan Estate, independent advisor to the [[British Museum]] and founder of the curatorial think tank Archaeology of the Final Decade.
=== Residents ===
Art Dubai presented its first edition of Residents, a 4-week residency programme hosted by the fair, in March 2018. Through this programme-cum-gallery section, multidisciplinary gallery artists from all over the world are invited to the UAE to create new works, in fully equipped Dubai and Abu Dhabi studio spaces, inspired by their experiences in the UAE<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.artdubai.ae/residents-2-2/|title=Art Dubai Residents - Art Dubai|last=Dubai|first=Art|work=Art Dubai|access-date=2018-04-09|language=en-US}}</ref>. The artists’ selection of works are displayed in a special exhibition area at the fair. The 2019 edition of Residents will focus exclusively on Latin America.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artdubai.ae/residents-2/2019/|title=Residents - Art Dubai|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Bawwaba ===
Art Dubai 2019 will see the launch of Bawwaba, a unique gallery section, located within the main gallery halls. The section will feature projects by individual artists or galleries, located in or focused on the Middle East, Africa, Central and South Asia as well as Latin America.
The inaugural edition of Bawwaba will be curated by French-Cameroonian curator Élise Atangana, and focus on highly conceptual works including videos, installations and murals. The section aims to give visitors a curated reading of the Global South, acting, as its name suggests, as a gateway to current artistic developments from these regions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cdn.artdubai.ae/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/AD19_PR_Art-Dubai-Announces-Gallery-Line-Up-For-Its-2019-Edition_EN.pdf|title=Art Dubai|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== The Global Art Forum == The Global Art Forum is the largest annual arts conference in the Middle East and Asia and takes place every year at Art Dubai.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.guggenheim.org/blogs/map/vernacular-curatorial-practice-in-the-united-arab-emirates|title=Vernacular Curatorial Practice in the United Arab Emirates|date=2016-04-26|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref> The conference features live talks, panel discussions and performances by regional and international thought leaders, artists, curators and writers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.buro247.me/culture/arts/buro-24-7-middle-east-s-complete-guide-to-art-duba.html|title=Buro 24/7 Middle East's complete guide to Art Dubai|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref> Previous speakers include high-profile figures such as [[Hans Ulrich Obrist]], [[Michael Stipe]] and [[Christo]]. In 2018, the Global Art Forum was co-directed by Noah Raford and Marlies Wirth with Commissioner [[Shumon Basar]] and held under the title 'I Am Not a Robot', focusing on the timely theme of power, paranoia and potentials of automation.
== Education == Art Dubai’s non-for-profit educational programming, provides programmes for children through to post-graduates. Art Dubai’s education initiatives include Campus Art Dubai, a community art school for UAE-based artists, curators, writers, designers and enthusiasts, Forum Fellows, a fellowship that brings together young curators and writers from the Middle East; and The Sheikha Manal Little Artist Program for children aged 5 to 17. The fair also has an internship and volunteer programme.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.harpersbazaararabia.com/art/exhibitions/art-dubai-2016|title=Art Dubai 2016: All Roads Connect|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref>
== Art Dubai Portraits == In Spring 2017, the fair started producing Art Dubai Portraits, a series of 1- and 3-minute films focusing on artists that are connected to the fair through its programming and participating galleries. Unique in showing the artists’ personal- and work-spaces as well as capturing their personality, the Art Dubai Portraits serve as a one-of-a-kind resource for curators and researchers working on the art from the region.
== Economic Impact == In March 2016, the fairs’ parent company, Art Dubai Fair FZ LLC (The Art Dubai Group), released the results of an independent survey for Art Week 2015 (March 18–25, 2015). The results show that the total economic impact the Art Dubai and Design Days Dubai events have on the local economy and service sector totaled US $35 million across seven days.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/gn-focus/special-reports/events/art-week-paints-dubai-green-with-dh128-million-economic-contribution-1.1682149|title=Art Week paints Dubai green with Dh128 million economic contribution|last=team|first=By the GN Focus|date=2016-03-01|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/art-dubai-said-contribute-35m-local-economy-623450.html#.V7BX2_l95hG|title=Art Dubai said to contribute $35m to local economy|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/dubai-fair-showcases-success-art-10th-190215675.html?ref=gs|title=Dubai fair showcases success in art in 10th year|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref>
[http://suzinassif.com/art-exhibitions-and-events-dubai/ Art Exhibitions and Events Dubai]

{{notability|Television|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Artzooka! | image = | genre = [[Children's television series|Children's]] | narrated = [[Jeremie Saunders]] | composer = | country = [[Canada]]
[[Germany]] | num_seasons = 3 | num_episodes = 357 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = Arnie Zipursky, Charles Falzon | producer = | cons_producer = | cinematography = | runtime = 20 minutes | company = [[CCI Entertainment]]
MotionWorks | distributor = [[9 Story Media Group]] | channel = [[CBC Television]]
[[Nickelodeon (Germany)]] | first_aired = September 21, 2010 | last_aired = April 13, 2012 | related = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Artzooka!''''' is a Canadian/German TV series revolving around creating art projects. It is a co-production between Canadian studio CCI Entertainment{{cite web|title=Artzooka! |url=http://www.canadaonscreen.ca/productions/television/artzooka |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120928040921/http://www.canadaonscreen.ca/productions/television/artzooka |dead-url=yes |archive-date=28 September 2012 |publisher=canadaonscreen.ca |accessdate=3 December 2013 }}{{cite web|title=Artzooka!|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1sCLGXhfp-U|publisher=youtube.com|accessdate=3 December 2013}} and german company MotionWorks. ==Characters== The show has some characters at points in the series. The two main characters are the host, Jeremie, who walks the viewer through the steps of each art project, and an animated character, "Paper Bag", who stars in his own little short film at the end of every episode. ==International Syndication== ''Artzooka!'' is aired in various countries, and each version has its own host. The Canadian and American versions are both hosted by Jeremie Saunders. {|class=wikitable |- !Country !Network |- | {{ISR}} | [[Arutz HaYeladim]] |- | {{CAN}} | [[CBC Television]]
[[BBC Kids]] |- | {{GBR}} | [[Pop (UK and Ireland)|Pop]]
[[Pop Max]] |- | {{USA}} | [[Qubo]] [http://www.qubo.com:80/shows/artzooka/web/20130130115629/ Artzooka on Qubo]
[[MundoMax]]
