page.title: Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum

revision.text:
{{Infobox Museum |name = Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum |image = Edited outside sin.jpeg |imagesize = |caption = New Location for the Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum in Nashville, TN |map_type = |map_caption = |latitude = |longitude = |established = 2006 |dissolved = |location = 401 Gay Street
[[Nashville]], [[Tennessee]] 37219
USA |type = [[Hall of Fame]] and [[Museum]] |visitors = |director = Joe Chambers |curator = |publictransit = |website = [http://www.musicianshalloffame.com/ www.musicianshalloffame.com] }} [[File:Musicians Hall of Fame Logo.jpeg|thumb|Official Logo]] The '''Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum''' (MHOF) honors all musicians regardless of genre or instrument. The MHOF timeline starts with the beginning of recorded music and inductees are nominated by current members of the [[American Federation of Musicians]] and by other music industry professionals. == First museum == The museum first opened June 6, 2006 at 301 6th Ave. S., [[Nashville, Tennessee]] Exhibits consisted of instruments owned and played by well-known artists as well as behind-the-scenes session musicians. These musicians were often the house studio musicians in cities such as [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Los Angeles]], [[Detroit]], [[Nashville]], [[Muscle Shoals]] and [[New York City]]. These musicians were often the unsung heroes behind the hits of many great artists. These relatively small groups of players often recorded the majority of hits in the 1950s, 1960s, 1970s and 1980s. The museum was voted venue of the year by the [[Meeting Professionals International]] in 2008. == Inductees == 2007 (1st Annual) – [[The Funk Brothers]], [[The Nashville A-Team]], [[The Wrecking Crew (music)|The Wrecking Crew]], [[The Blue Moon Boys]], [[The Memphis Boys]], [[The Tennessee Three|The Tennessee Two]]. The inaugural ceremony was highlighted by the performances of [[Garth Brooks]], [[Vince Gill]], [[Peter Frampton]], [[George Jones]], [[Amy Grant]], [[Rodney Crowell]], [[B.J. Thomas]], and [[Dobie Gray]] honoring the evenings inductees. 2008 (2nd Annual) – [[Billy Sherrill]], [[The Crickets]], [[Al Kooper]], [[Duane Eddy]], [[The Memphis Horns]], [[Booker T and the MGs]], The [[Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section]] & Friends. [[Keith Richards]], [[Kid Rock]], [[Phil Everly]] and [[Lee Ann Womack]] were among the performers to welcome the inductees. Richards joined The Crickets on stage for a performance of Holly's "Don't Fade Away," which [[The Rolling Stones]] covered in 1964. 2009 (3rd Annual) – [[Chet Atkins]], [[Toto (band)|Toto]], [[Victor Feldman]], [[Charlie Daniels]], [[Fred Foster]], [[Billy Cox]], [[Paul Riser]], [[Dick Dale]]. Toto was joined on stage by [[Rascal Flatts]] to perform "Rosanna," "Hold The Line," "I'll Be Over You" and "Africa". [[Steve Wariner]], [[Paul Yandell]], [[Tony Joe White]] and [[Beach Boys]] guitarist [[Al Jardine]] were among the other performers at the ceremony. 2014 (4th Annual) – After a four-year absence due to relocating, the 2014 Induction Ceremony was held in their new location on January 28, 2014. The new inductees were [[Barbara Mandrell]], [[Peter Frampton]], [[Randy Bachmann]], [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]] and [[Double Trouble (band)|Double Trouble]], Corki Casey O'Dell, Velma Smith, [[Will Lee (bassist)|Will Lee]], [[Ben Keith]], Jimmy Capps, [[Buddy Guy]], [[Mike Curb]], and Rock legend [[Roy Orbison]] was also honored with a special posthumous honor - the 2014 "iconic riff" award for the famous guitar lick in his hit "Pretty Woman." http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2013/11/04/musicians-hall-of-fame-to-induct-barbara-mandrell-peter-frampton-more/ 2016 (5th Annual) - Musicians Hall of Fame held its 5th annual Induction Ceremony and Concert. Inductees included: [[Garth Brooks]] and his studio musicians [[The G-Men]], the studio musicians from [[Sigma Sound Studio in Philadelphia]], "Iconic Riff" winner [[Don Felder]] formerly with the Eagles for Hotel California, [[Ricky Skaggs]], "posthumously" [[Jerry Reed]], producer [[Allen Reynolds]], engineers [[Lou Bradley (recording engineer)|Lou Bradley]], [[Ron 'Snake' Reynolds]], [[Joe Tarsia]], and [[Mark Miller (recording engineer)|Mark Miller]]. Special guests included: [[Kenny G]], [[Bruce Hornsby]], [[Steve Wariner]], [[Russell Thompkins Jr.]] and [[Peter Frampton]]. == Closing and reopening == In February 2010, under the rules of [[eminent domain]], the city of Nashville purchased the MHOF property in order to make room for the [[Music City Center]] (new convention center). On August 29, 2013 the MHOF reopened on the first floor of the historic [[Nashville Municipal Auditorium]] just off the James Robertson Parkway exit at 401 Gay Street, Nashville, TN 37219.http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2013/08/27/musicians-hall-of-fame-reopens-in-nashville-after-three-year-absence/ The 200,000 square foot building houses the historic 10,000 seat Municipal Auditorium. The 68,000 sq. ft. exhibit floor, which was also Nashville's first convention center, will now house the museums artifacts and museum. == References == {{reflist|refs = {{cite news | first = Calvin | last = Gilbert | date = November 27, 2007 | title = Unsung Heroes Honored at Musicians Hall of Fame Induction | publisher = [[Country Music Television|CMT.com]] | url = http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1575159/unsung-heroes-honored-at-musicians-hall-of-fame-induction.jhtml | accessdate = June 14, 2013}} {{cite news | first = Daniel | last = Kreps | date = October 29, 2008 | title = Kid Rock, Keith Richards Help Induct Crickets, Muscle Shoals Into Musicians Hall of Fame | publisher = [[Rolling Stone]] | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/kid-rock-keith-richards-help-induct-crickets-muscle-shoals-into-musicians-hall-of-fame-20081029 | accessdate = June 14, 2013}} {{cite news | first = Calvin | last = Gilbert | date = October 13, 2009 | title = Rascal Flatts Perform With Toto During Musicians Hall of Fame Induction Ceremony | publisher = [[Country Music Television|CMT.com]] | url = http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1623747/rascal-flatts-perform-with-toto-during-musicians-hall-of-fame-induction-ceremony.jhtml | accessdate = June 14, 2013}} {{cite news | first = William | last = Williams | date = May 14, 2013 | title = Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum to open in June | publisher = [[NashvillePost.com]] | url = http://nashvillepost.com/blogs/postbusiness/2013/5/14/musicians_hall_of_fame_and_museum_to_open_in_june | accessdate = June 14, 2013}} {{cite news | first = Nancy | last = Amons | date = May 9, 2013 | title = Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum set to reopen with new exhibits | publisher = [[WSMV-TV]] | url = http://www.wsmv.com/story/22212728/musicians-hall-of-fame-and-museum-set-to-reopen-with-new-exhibits | accessdate = June 14, 2013}} }} ==See also== * [[List of music museums]] == External links == * [http://www.musicianshalloffame.com Official Website] [[Category:Music halls of fame]] [[Category:Halls of fame in Tennessee]] [[Category:Music museums in Tennessee]] [[Category:Museums in Nashville, Tennessee]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 2006]] [[Category:2006 establishments in Tennessee]] [[Category:Culture of Nashville, Tennessee]] [[Category:American Federation of Musicians]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} '''NVA''' is an arts organisation and charity based in [[Glasgow]], Scotland. It was founded in 1992 by [[Angus Farquhar]], a former member of the group [[Test Dept]]. The company's name is an acronym of ''nacionale vitae activa'', a Latin term meaning 'the right to influence public affairs'.<ref>[http://www.nva.org.uk/about/ About NVA.] Retrieved 3 March 2008.</ref>
The company is best known for its dramatic, large-scale environmental artworks in Scottish natural landscapes, building on the site-specific performances that Farquhar created with Test Dept. These works have included ''The Secret Sign'', ''The Path'', ''The Storr'' and ''Half Life''. The works are designed to involve local communities and to incorporate regeneration aspects that will benefit the landscapes in the future. For example, improvements were made to the footpaths around The Storr as part of the preparation for that work.
== ''The Secret Sign'' ==
''The Secret Sign'' took place at night on 9–16 May 1998 at The Devil's Pulpit, Finnich Glen, near [[Loch Lomond]]. Audience members were transported by bus (with the windows blacked out) to the site of the work, where they were given hard hats and wading boots. They were then escorted through the glen by members of the company. Various artistic interventions were visible along the way, including lights, sounds, birds of prey and live performance.<ref>[http://www.nva.org.uk/past-projects/the+secret+sign/ ''The Secret Sign''.] Documentation of event on NVA website. Retrieved 3 March 2008.</ref>
== ''The Path'' ==
''The Path'' was a two-hour night-time walk that took place from 19 May – 4 June 2000 at Glen Lyon in Perthshire. Like ''The Secret Sign'' it featured light, sound, performance and music, including Buddhist chant by Ani Choying Drolma.<ref>[http://www.nva.org.uk/past-projects/the+path/ ''The Path''.] Documentation of event on NVA website. Retrieved 3 March 2008.</ref>
== ''The Storr'' ==
''The Storr'' took place at night from 1 August – 17 September 2005 at [[The Storr]], a rocky hill in [[Trotternish]] on the [[Isle of Skye]]. Audience members were bussed to the site from bases in [[Portree]] and [[Staffin]] and kitted out with head torches and walking sticks. They were then led up to the base of the Old Man of Storr, a natural rock formation. Like the earlier works, the walk was marked by lights, sounds, music and performance. The work contained music by [[Geir Jenssen]] and [[Paul Mounsey]], live performance by [[Scottish Gaelic language|Gaelic]] singer Ann Martin and recordings of the works of Gaelic poet [[Sorley MacLean]].<ref>[http://www.nva.org.uk/past-projects/the+storr+unfolding+landscape/ ''The Storr''.] Documentation of event on NVA website. Retrieved 3 March 2008.</ref> Other elements of ''The Storr'' included a series of [[LED]] stars which together made up the largest light sculpture ever seen in the UK.<ref name="guardian">"[http://arts.guardian.co.uk/features/story/0,11710,1532752,00.html Call of the wild]". ''The Guardian'' 21 July 2005. Retrieved 3 March 2008.</ref> The total cost of mounting the work was £1 million.<ref name="guardian"/>
== ''Half Life'' ==
''Half Life'' took place at [[Kilmartin Glen]], [[Argyll]] from 4–16 September 2007, and was a collaboration between NVA and the [[National Theatre of Scotland]]. It consisted of two parts: a daytime element, where visitors could explore a series of sites and installations based around known and rarely seen prehistoric landmarks; and a night-time element, consisting of an outdoor production staged in a forest location at the entrance to the glen, centred on a sculptural set constructed from felled logs.<ref>[http://www.nva.org.uk/past-projects/half+life/ ''Half Life''.] Documentation of event on NVA website. Retrieved 3 March 2008.</ref>
== ''White Bike Plan'' ==
In April 2010 NVA re-enacted Witte Fietsenplan (White Bike Plan), a free transport programme by the Provos, the Dutch counter culture movement of the 1960s. NVA released 50 white bicycles across the city, which were available for the audience of Glasgow International Festival of Visual Art to travel between venues for the duration of the festival.<ref>[http://www.nva.org.uk/past-projects/witte+feitsenplan+white+bike+plan-24/ ''White Bike Plan''.] Documentation of event on NVA website. Retrieved 8 February 2011.</ref>
== ''Glasgow Harvest'' ==
NVA hosted the first Glasgow Harvest in August 2010 at the Hidden Gardens. Glasgow Harvest was a celebration of urban farming, and encouraged visitors to participate in a mass open-air meal prepared using their home-grown ingredients. Visitors were invited to contribute to an immense jam wall, sample edible punk haircuts, and submit to competition the creative containers they had used to grow plants. Glasgow's allotments made 12 different soups and 20 local schools participated in the Double Rubble Chip Challenge - making chips at Harvest from potatoes they had grown from seed in their playgrounds.
== ''Speed of Light'' == Speed of Light was a major [[Edinburgh International Festival]] 2012 commission, one of Scotland's signature contributions to the [[2012 Cultural Olympiad|Olympic cultural programme]]. Conceived and produced by NVA, the transformation of [[Arthur's Seat]], [[Edinburgh]]'s iconic mountain, combined innovative public art and sport. Using energy-harvesting technologies to illuminate walkers and specially designed battery-powered light suits worn by runners, Speed of Light harnessed collective action to create a multi-layered night-time animation. NVA's Speed of Light also investigated the physical and emotional aspects to endurance running and the extent to which the power of the mind can override physical pain. A series of related blogs, web portraits, events, lectures and co-commissions were presented in partnership with eight of the [[Edinburgh Festival]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Speed of Light: Overview|url=http://nvaspeedoflight.org.uk/#!/page/2/Overview|}}</ref>
== List of works ==
*''Stormy Waters'' (1995) *''Pain'' (one-man show by Graham Cunnington) (1996) *''Virtual World Orchestra'' (1997) *''The Secret Sign'' (1998) *''National Day for Britain, Expo 98'' (1998) *''Grand Central'' (1999) *''The Gimmick'' (1999) *''The Path'' (2000) *''The Hidden Gardens'' (2003) *''The Storr'' (2005) *''Radiance'' (2005) *''Half Life'' (2007) *''Spirit'' (2008) *''White Bike Plan'' (2010) *''Glasgow Harvest'' (2010) *''Speed of Light'' (2012)
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.nva.org.uk NVA website]

revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} '''Naval Nuclear Propulsion Information (NNPI)''' is a category of [[intellectual capital]] defined by the [[United States Navy]] to be "classified or unclassified information concerning the design, arrangement, development, manufacture, testing, operation, administration, training, maintenance, and repair of the propulsion plants of naval nuclear-powered ships and prototypes, including the associated shipboard and shore-based nuclear support facilities.." <ref>{{cite web |url=http://doni.daps.dla.mil/Directives/09000%20General%20Ship%20Design%20and%20Support/09-200%20Propulsion%20Plants%20Support/N9210.3%20(Unclas%20Portion).pdf |title=OPNAVINST N9210.3, SAFEGUARDING OF NAVAL NUCLEAR PROPULSION INFORMATION (NNPI), 6/7/2010, Unclassified Portion, page 1-1, Definition|accessdate=February 2012}}</ref>
Not all NNPI is [[classified information]]. While most NNPI is sensitive, the Navy recognizes that the public has an interest in [[Natural environment|environmental]], [[safety]], and [[health]] information, and that the basic [[research]] carried out by the Navy can be useful to [[industry]]. Unclassified information is therefore marked with the acronym "U-NNPI", but is still restricted as [[wikt:NOFORN|NOFORN]].<ref>See OPNAVINST N9210.3, esp. Chapters 3 and 4.</ref>
NNPI is explicitly protected information and is not released to the general public without authority. Those who release even NNPI-U without authority may be administratively punished, and even [[criminal law|criminally]] in the case of NNPI-C.{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} NNPI is restricted from disclosure under the Arms Export Control Act, [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/22/2778 22 USC §§2778] and [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/22/2794 2794(7)]; such information is listed in the [http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr;sid=d148ef6a9390b1e27fc09865c734666c;rgn=div5;view=text;node=22%3A1.0.1.13.60;idno=22;cc=ecfr US Munitions List, 22 CFR §121.1], Category VI, paragraph (g).
In some instances, small events that would normally be reported as "Events" or LOC (Loss of Control) to the [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission]] from other licensees can be classified as NNPI-C.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://azstarnet.com/news/national/dangerous-tennessee-radioactive-spill-kept-from-public-papers-sealed/article_70fed1e3-e100-5f8e-91b6-4535b39289d6.html |title=Dangerous Tennessee radioactive spill kept from public; papers sealed |author=Associated Press |publisher=Arizona Daily Star |date=2007-08-21 }}</ref> This designation differs for similar "events" that occur on a secret network, which are referred to as "spillage".
==References== {{more footnotes|date=May 2008}} <references/>
* OPNAVINST N9210.3, SAFEGUARDING OF NAVAL NUCLEAR PROPULSION INFORMATION (NNPI), 6/7/2010

{{Infobox ancient site |name = Naveta of Es Tudons<!-- required --> |native_name = Naveta d'Es Tudons |alternate_name = Naveta des Tudons |image =Tudons01.jpg |alt = Naveta of Es Tudons |caption = Façade and side wall of the Naveta d'Es Tudons |map = |map_caption = |map_type = Spain Menorca |map_alt = |coordinates = {{coord|40.003128|3.891558|region:ES|format=dms|display=inline,title}} |map_size = |location = [[Menorca]], [[Balearic Islands]], Spain |region = |type = Burial site |part_of = |length = {{convert|13.60|m}}<ref name=Lagarda/> |width = {{convert|6.40|m}}<ref name=Lagarda/> |area = |height = {{convert|4.50|m}}<ref name=Lagarda/> |builder = |material = limestone |built = 2000-1000 BC<ref name=chap>{{harvnb|Chapman|Grant|1997|pp=71}}</ref> |abandoned = 750 BC |epochs = |cultures = pre-[[Talaiotic culture|Talaiotic age]] |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = 1959 |archaeologists = |condition = restored |ownership = |management = |public_access = yes |website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> |notes = }}
The '''Naveta d'Es Tudons''', or '''Naveta of Es Tudons''' (in Menorquí, ''naveta'', or ''naueta'', a diminutive form of ''nau'', means ''nave'',<ref>The monument is sometimes also called ''Nau d'Es Tudons''</ref> and ''Es Tudons'', lit. ''the woodpigeons'', is the name of the place),<ref name=Grinsell>{{harvnb|Grinsell|1975|p=194}}</ref> is the most remarkable [[megalithic]] [[chamber tomb]] in the [[Balearic Islands|Balearic island]] of [[Menorca]], Spain.
It is located in the Western part of the island, on the [[Ciutadella de Menorca]]-[[Port Mahon|Mahón]] road, approximately 3 miles out from Ciutadella, and 200 m south of the road. It stands on slightly rising ground in a sloping valley.<ref>{{harvnb|James|1957|p=67}} [https://archive.org/stream/prehistoricrelig00jame#page/n71/mode/2up]</ref> Currently the Naveta d'Es Tudons is open to the public for visits (except for its interior as a measure of protection). It is one of the main tourist attractions of Menorca.
== History== In Menorca and Majorca there are several dozen habitational and funerary [[naveta]] complexes, some of which similarly comprise two storeys.<ref name=Grinsell/><ref name="GeorgGerster" /><ref name=fdz/> Navetas (''navetes'' in Menorquí) are chronologically pre-Talaiotic (i.e. prior to the [[Talaiotic culture|Talaiotic age]]) constructions.<ref name=fdz>{{harvnb|Fernández Miranda|1997|pp=60–61}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spanisharts.com/arquitectura/imagenes/prehistoria/i_navetas.html|title=Navetas, Menorca, Baleares Islands |work=The History Of The Spanish Architecture}}</ref> Navetas were described in the early 19th century but not excavated until the 20th, notably during the 1960s and 1970s.<ref name="GeorgGerster">{{harvnb|Gerster|2007|p=250 (Es Tudons in Menorca, Spain)}}</ref> Navetas were first given their name by the rather imaginative Dr Juan Ramis (1818) from their resemblance to upturned boats.<ref>{{harvnb|Grinsell|1975|p=193}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Hoskin|Morales Núñez|1991|p=25}}</ref>
The Naveta d'Es Tudons is the largest and best preserved funerary naveta in Menorca. The Naveta d'Es Tudons served as collective [[ossuary]] between 1200 and 750 BC.<ref>{{harvnb|Chapman|Grant|1997|pp=69–71}}</ref> The lower chamber was for stashing the disarticulated bones of the dead after the flesh had been removed<ref name="PhilLee">Phil Lee, ''The Rough Guide to Menorca'', Rough Guides, 2001, 288 p. 187.</ref> while the upper chamber was probably used for the drying of recently placed corpses.<ref>{{harvnb|Blake |Knapp|2005| p=170}}</ref> Radiocarbon dating of the bones found in the different funerary navetas in Menorca indicate a usage period between about 1130-820 BC,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Micó |first=Rafael|title=Radiocarbon dating and balearic prehistory: reviewing the periodization of the prehistoric sequence|journal=Radiocarbon |year=2006|volume=48|issue=3|pages=421–434 |url=https://journals.uair.arizona.edu/index.php/radiocarbon/article/view/2886/2649|accessdate=8 May 2012|issn=0033-8222}}</ref> but the navetas like the Naveta d'Es Tudons are probably older. Pre-Talaiotic constructions are dated using an uncalibrated radiocarbon chronology from 1640 to 1400 BC.<ref name=fdz/> The navetas used for communal burial rituals are dated to the late second millennium and early first millennium BC.<ref name=Lagarda>{{cite web|last=Lagarda i Mata|first=Ferran|title=Es Tudons|url=http://www.menorcaweb.net/arqueologia/menorca/arqme64.htm|work=Menorcaweb.net|accessdate=8 May 2012}}</ref><ref name="chap" />
Although listed in the [[Bien de Interés Cultural|Spanish heritage register]] on 3 June 1931 ([http://toolserver.org/%7Eplatonides/wlm/ids.php?bic=RI-51-0003442&userlang=en RI-51-0003442]), the naveta d'Es Tudons was excavated and restored by archaeologist [[Lluís Pericot García]] in 1959-1960. It was found to contain the remains of at least 100 skeletons (one with trepanned skull). Various recovered objects like [[bronze]] bracelets or bone and ceramic buttons <ref name=Grinsell/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.menorcaweb.com/reports/archaeological-sites/naveta-des-tudons/|work=MenorcaWeb.com |title=Naveta des Tudons}}</ref> are today on display in the [[Museu de Menorca]] in Mahón. Restoration works were carried out and the two or three missing courses at the top were put back in place.<ref name=Grinsell/> For protection, it was surrounded at a distance by a recently restored modern dry stone field wall.<ref>Dominique Auzias, Jean-Paul Labourdette, ''Baléares, Ibiza — Minorque — Majorque'', Le Petit Fûté, 2012, 336 p., p. 281 : "Inutile de vous extasier sur le mur de pierre sèche qui entoure la Naveta, il est de construction récente" ("There is no need for one to enthuse about the dry stone wall surrounding the Naveta, its construction is recent.")</ref>
== Architecture == [[File:Plan and Section of Nau d'Es Tudons 1912.png|thumb|left|Plan and section of the unrestored naveta (1912): ''(a)'' low door, ''(b)'' narrow slab-roofed passage, ''(c)'' long rectangular chamber.<ref>{{harvnb|Peet|1912|p=73}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Cartailhac|1892}}</ref>]]
The shape of the Naveta d'Es Tudons is that of a boat upside down, with the stern as its trapezoidal façade and the bow as its rounded apse. Its groundplan is an elongated semicircle. Externally, the edifice is 14.5 m long by 6.5 m wide and 4.55 m high but it would originally have been 6 m high.<ref name=Grinsell/> It is orientated SWS/ENE, the entrance being at the SWS, in the centre of the slightly slanted (or battered) façade.
The front, side walls and apse of the edifice consist of successive horizontal corbelled courses of huge rectangular or square [[limestone]] blocks dressed with a hammer<ref>{{harvnb|Guillemard|1907|pp=465–467}}</ref> and fitted together without mortar, with an all-round foundation course of blocks of even greater size laid on edge.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artehistoria.jcyl.es/artesp/obras/19331.htm|title= Naveta dels Tudons (Ciutadella, Menorca)]|work=artehistoria|quote=''Toda la construcción se ejecutó mediante sillares de buen tamaño dispuestos en hiladas regulares, excepto el zócalo hecho a base de bloques de mayor tamaño que sirven de cimentación.''}}</ref>
The narrow, low entrance doorway (0.57 m x 0.75 m) is rebated to receive a closing slab. The once sealed-off entrance leads by a short, flag-roofed passage to an antechamber 1.3 m long and then another short passage to the main or lower chamber (7.45 m x 2.45 m), the ceiling of which is made of giant horizontal slabs inserted into the side walls, with an average span of 1.5 m ''c.'' 2.25 m above the floor. Above this is an upper chamber which is accessible from the upper part of the antechamber. It is slightly shorter (7.10 m) and narrower (1.90 m) than the lower chamber, with a similar although much lower (0.85 m) ceiling of horizontal slabs.<ref name=Grinsell/> These have holes in them, presumably for ventilation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stonefoundation.org/gallery/sp02.html|title= Tektonika, a photo gallery - an exhibit of photographs of the stonework of the Balearic Islands & the Catalan mainland|work=Stonefoundation.org}}</ref>
{{clear left}} [[File:Naveta des tudons.jpg|250px|right|thumb|The edifice at dawn, behind its modern wall]]
== Folklore == According to Phil Lee, the author of ''The Rough Guide to Menorca'', folkloric memories of the navetas' original purpose may have survived into modern times, for the Menorcans were loath to go near these odd-looking and solitary monuments until well into the 19th century.<ref name="PhilLee" />
A modern tragic lore tells that two giants were competing for the love of a girl. They agreed that one would build a naveta and the other would dig a water well and the first to finish would marry the girl. As the giant who was building the naveta was about to lay the last stone, the other struck water. Mad with jealousy, the first giant threw the last stone (the one that is missing from the top of the façade) into the well, killing the other giant. Then, feeling remorse, he killed himself. It is said that the girl died a spinster and was buried in the naveta.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} {{clr}}
== Gallery == <gallery mode="packed" heights="150"> File:Naveta tudons 01.jpg|West South-West front end (2008) File:Naveta des Tudons.jpg|South South-East side wall (2007) File:Naveta Tudons.jpg|North North-West side wall (2004) File:Tudons02.jpg|Apse (2006) </gallery>

revision.text:
{{Redirect|Power Up|other uses|Power up (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox organization | logo = POWERUP.png | logo_size = 180px | type = [[501(c)(3)]] [[non-profit organization]] | founded_date = 2000 | founder = K. Pearson Brown
Stacy Codikow
Amy Shomer {{cite journal|journal=The Advocate|date=27 Mar 2001|title=Power up!|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BmMEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA49&lpg=PA49&dq=K.+Pearson+Brown+founder+%22Power+up%22&source=bl&ots=VsJ2djU0tB&sig=RiknSaLTyQeAwnPtTxDIo13w-48&hl=en&sa=X&ei=9cENT8DMFISY8QOSi-WjBg&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=K.%20Pearson%20Brown%20founder%20%22Power%20up%22&f=false}} | location = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[United States|U.S.]] | origins = | key_people = Stacy Codikow, Executive director
Lisa Thrasher, President of Film Production & Distribution | area_served = | focus = [[Motion picture]]s | method = Funding, producing | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = Professional Organization of Women in Entertainment Reaching Up! | homepage =http://www.powerupfilms.org/ | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''POWER UP''' (the "'''P'''rofessional '''O'''rganization of '''W'''omen in '''E'''ntertainment '''R'''eaching Up") is an [[United States|American]] [[non-profit organization]] and film [[production company]] with the stated mission "to promote the visibility and integration of [[lesbian|gay women]] in entertainment, the arts, and all forms of media". It was founded in 2000 by [[K. Pearson Brown]], [[Stacy Codikow]] and [[Amy Shomer]].{{cite web |url=http://www.power-up.net/celebrity_guests_include.htm |title=Challenging Perception through Film, POWER UP |accessdate=2007-05-15 |work=POWER UP |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070427101417/http://www.power-up.net/celebrity_guests_include.htm |archivedate = 2007-04-27}} Its members include women and men, gay and [[heterosexual|straight]]. POWER UP provides funding and assistance to filmmakers, as well as producing its own films. After several [[short film]]s, its first [[feature film]] was the [[comedy film|comedy]] ''[[Itty Bitty Titty Committee]]'' directed by [[Jamie Babbit]].{{cite web |url=http://www.afterellen.com/people/2007/2/powerlesbians?page=0%2C1 |title=The Top 13 Power Lesbians in Entertainment in 2007 |last=Lo |first=Malinda |date=2007-02-27|work=AfterEllen.com |accessdate=2007-05-15}} In 2004, POWER UP was awarded the Leadership Award by the [[National Gay and Lesbian Task Force]]. In 2001 K. Pearson Brown, one of the founding members, brought a sexual harassment suit against another founding member, Stacey Codikow. Codikow counter-sued alleging that Brown had made sexual overtures towards her and accusing Brown of defamation. Codikow also demanded Brown's resignation on the grounds that she was bisexual, and Brown later resigned. Both suits were dropped in late 2002.{{cite news|last=Welkos|first=Robert W.|title=Sexual harassment suit roils lesbian industry group|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/nov/02/entertainment/et-newwelkos2|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=November 2, 2002}} {{cite journal|last=Maynard|first=Kevin|title=Case dismissed|journal=The Advocate|date=24 Dec 2002|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JGQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA17&lpg=PA17&dq=%22power+up%22+sexual+harassment+Brown+Codikow&source=bl&ots=aAN5uEfiQk&sig=kIHobKruXarxLuapVbMQPZTNvkQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=c8QNT9GQGZTo8QP8zOGbBg&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%22power%20up%22%20sexual%20harassment%20Brown%20Codikow&f=false}}{{cite journal|last=Maynard|first=Kevin|title=She said, she said|journal=The Advocate|date=10 Dec 2002|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XGQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA27&lpg=PA27&dq=K.+Pearson+Brown+%22Power+up%22&source=bl&ots=GsnsEoq1p3&sig=6heflc-CcsWr0yXy_EGoZmpK3IA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HMENT8CLH5P08QPDy93pBQ&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=K.%20Pearson%20Brown%20%22Power%20up%22&f=false}} ==Films== * [[2001 in film|2001]]: ''[[Stuck (2001 film)|Stuck]]'' - [[Jamie Babbit]] * 2001: ''[[Chicken Night]]'' - [[Lisa Ginsburg]] * 2001: ''[[Breaking Up Really Sucks]]'' - [[Jennifer McGlone]] * [[2003 in film|2003]]: ''[[Give or Take an Inch]]'' - [[Lee Friedlander (film director)|Lee Friedlander]] * 2003: ''[[Fly Cherry]]'' - [[Jessica Sharzer]] * 2003: ''[[D.E.B.S. (2003 film)|D.E.B.S.]]'' - [[Angela Robinson]] * 2003: ''Intent'' - [[Mary Ann Marino]] * [[2004 in film|2004]]: ''[[Little Black Boot]]'' - [[Colette Burson]] * 2004: ''[[The Nearly Unadventurous Life of Zoe Cadwaulder]]'' - [[Buboo Kakati]] * 2004: ''[[Billy's Dad Is a Fudge-Packer]]'' - [[Jamie Donahue]] * [[2005 in film|2005]]: ''[[Promtroversy]]'' - [[Leanna Creel]] * 2005: ''[[Starcrossed (film)|Starcrossed]]'' - [[James Burkhammer]] * [[2007 in film|2007]]: ''[[Itty Bitty Titty Committee]]'' - [[Jamie Babbit]] * 2008: ''The Nitty Gritty Behind the Itty Bitty Titty Committee'' - Lisa Thrasher * 2014: ''[[Girltrash: All Night Long]]'' - Alexandra Kondracke ==See also== {{Portal|LGBT}} *[[List of LGBT-related organizations]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.powerupfilms.org/ Official site] *{{imdb company|0026662}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Power Up}} [[Category:Film production companies of the United States]] [[Category:Lesbian organizations in the United States]] [[Category:LGBT arts organizations]] [[Category:LGBT organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2000]] [[Category:Women's film organizations]] [[Category:501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations]]

page.title: Papal tombs in old St. Peter's Basilica

revision.text:
[[File:Grimaldi sketch.jpg|thumb|right|A sketch by Giacomo Grimaldi of the interior of St. Peter's during its reconstruction, showing the temporary placement of some of the tombs|alt=A drawing of the interior of St. Peters]] The '''papal tombs in old St. Peter's Basilica''' were the final resting places of the [[pope]]s, most which dated from the fifth to sixteenth centuries. The majority of these tombs were destroyed during the sixteenth through seventeenth century demolition of [[old St. Peter's Basilica]], except for one which was destroyed during the [[Arab raid against Rome|Saracen Sack of the church]] in 846. The remainder were transferred in part to new [[St. Peter's Basilica]], which stands on the site of the original basilica, and a handful of other [[churches of Rome]]. ==History== Along with the repeated translations from the ancient [[catacombs of Rome]] and two fourteenth century fires in [[Basilica of St. John Lateran]], the rebuilding of St. Peter's is responsible for the destruction of approximately half of all [[List of extant papal tombs|papal tombs]]. As a result, [[Donato Bramante]], the chief architect of modern St. Peter's Basilica, has been remembered as "''Mastro Ruinante''". Although the original basilica's construction was begun during the reign of emperor [[Constantine I]] and completed in the fourth century, [[Pope Leo I]] (440–461) was the first pope buried in the Constantian basilica.Reardon, 2004, p. 40. Over the centuries, both the atrium, chapels, and the nave of the basilica were packed with papal tombs, which were juggled between different sections of the church as construction took place on each section of the basilica. All that remains of the original tombs are a few sarcophagi and sculptural fragments.Reardon, 2004, p. 272. Allegedly, [[Pope Julius II]], the pope who initiated the destruction of the Constantinian basilica, wished to clear space for a "monstrous" tomb of his own by [[Michelangelo]].Reardon, 2004, p. 274. Very little is known about the placement and appearance of the original tombs: one of the most valuable accounts is that of church canon and historian [[Giacomo Grimaldi]] (a senator of Genoa and the father of [[Girolamo Grimaldi-Cavalleroni]]), who sketched the tombs as they were moved around the basilica on the way to their destruction;Grimaldi, Giacomo. Ed. R. Niggl. 1972. ''Descrizione della Basilica Antica di S. Pietro in Vaticano: Codice Barberini Latino 2733''. Vatican City. Grimaldi's sketches record the shape and complexity of the early tombs, many of which were three-tiered. A few destroyed papal tombs are also detailed in the writings of [[Alphonsus Ciacconius]].Reardon, 2004, p. 12. Not all popes were buried in Rome. ''See [[list of non-extant papal tombs]]'' ==Papal tombs== {| id="toc" class="toc" summary="Class" ! {{MediaWiki:Toc}} |- | style="text-align:center;"|[[#400–500|400–500]]{{·}}[[#500–600|500–600]]{{·}}[[#600–700|600–700]]{{·}}[[#700–800|700–800]]{{·}}[[#800–900|800–900]]{{·}}[[#900–1000|900–1000]]{{·}}[[#1000–1100|1000–1100]]{{·}}[[#1100–1200|1100–1200]]{{·}}[[#1200–1300|1200–1300]]{{·}}[[#1300–1400|1300–1400]]{{·}}[[#1400–1500|1400–1500]]{{·}}[[#1500–1600|1500–1600]] |} :''Partially extant, moved, or rebuilt tombs are shown with a darkened background''. [[File:Alfarano map.jpg|thumb|right|A map, circa 1590, by [[Tiberio Alfarano]] of the interior of Old Saint Peter's, noting the locations of the original chapels and tombs.|alt=A map of the interior of Old St. Peter's]] [[File:Expulsão de átila.jpg|thumb|right|Algardi's ''Fuga d'Attila'', above the altar containing the translated remains of Pope Leo I, "the Great"|alt=A photo of Algardi's ''Fuga d'Attila'']] [[File:Tomb of pope Gregorius I.jpg|thumb|right|The altar above the translated remains of Pope Gregory I, "the Great"|alt=A photo of an altar]] [[File:Archive plan for the original Tomb of Pope Leo III.jpg|thumb|right|A drawing of the original tomb of Pope Leo III|alt=A drawing of the tomb of Pope Leo II]] [[File:Atrium of Old Saint Peter.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Atrium (architecture)|atrium]] of Old St. Peter's Basilica, a popular site for tombs|alt=A drawing of the atrium of Old St. Peter's]] [[File:De sacris aedificiis a Costantino Magno constructis synopsis historica pag. 56 Tab. XV.jpg|thumb|Drawing of papal tombs, from ''De sacris aedificiis...'' by [[Giovanni Ciampini]] (1693)]] [[File:De sacris aedificiis a Costantino Magno constructis synopsis historica pag. 57 Tab. Tomb by [[Giovanni Tomacelli]] among the first destroyed during the demolition.Reardon, 2004, p. 140. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|{{anchor|1400–1500}}1404–1406 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| [[File:Innocent VII.jpg|70px]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Innocent VII|Innocent VII]]''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|Originally buried in the Chapel of Saints Peter and Paul, moved to the Chapel of St. Thomas in 1455, moved into a mid-fifteenth century copy of the original sarcophagus on September 12, 1606Reardon, 2004, pp. 141–142. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| 1447–1455 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| [[File:Paus Nicolaas V door Peter Paul Rubens.jpg|70px]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Nicholas V|Nicholas V]]''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|Moved from the left outer aisle of Old Saint Peter's to the right outer aisle. Still monument by [[Mino da Fiesole]], but not sarcophagus, destroyed during the demolition.Reardon, 2004, p. 153. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| 1464–1471 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| [[File:Paul II.JPG|70px]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Paul II|Paul II]]''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|Effigy by [[Giovanni Dalmata]]; figures and bas-reliefs by [[Mino da Fiesole]]. Monument moved in 1544 and torn down in seventeenth century; sarcophagus survived demolition.Reardon, 2004, p. 163. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| 1471–1484 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| [[File:Sixtus IV.png|70px]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Sixtus IV|Sixtus IV]]''', '''''[[Franciscan|O.F.M.]]''''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|Sculpted by [[Antonio del Pollaiolo]]. Originally located in the choir chapel of Old Saint Peter's; moved in 1610 to the sacristy; moved in 1625 to the Chapel del Coro in new Saint Peter's; combined with Julius II in 1926; moved again in 1940s.Reardon, 2004, p. 167. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| 1484–1492 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| [[File:Innocent VIII.JPG|70px]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Innocent VIII|Innocent VIII]]''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|Sculpted by [[Antonio del Pollaiolo]]. First papal tomb to depict a live pope rather than a deathbed effigy; originally placed in the Oratory of Our Lady in Old St. Peter's; moved to the sudarium on September 5, 1606 during the demolition. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|{{anchor|1500–1600}}1503–1503 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| [[File:Pius III, Nordisk familjebok.png|70px]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Pius III|Pius III]]''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|Sculpted by [[Sebastiano Ferrucci]]. Originally built in Old Saint Peter's; last papal mausoleum erected in Old St. Peter's; moved to Sant'Andrea della Valle during the reign of Paul V.Reardon, 2004, p. 177. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| 1523–1534 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|[[File:Clement VII. Sebastiano del Piombo. c.1531..jpg|70px]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Clement VII|Clement VII]]''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|Originally buried in a brick tomb in Old Saint Peter's; current tomb is across from that of Leo X, another Medici pope in Santa Maria sopra MinervaReardon, 2004, p. 182. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| 1534–1549 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|[[File:Tizian 083b.jpg|70px]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Paul III|Paul III]]''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|Sculpted by [[Guglielmo della Porta]]. Moved in 1599.Reardon, 2004, pp. 185–186. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| 1550–1555 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|[[File:Julius III.jpg|70px]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Julius III|Julius III]]''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|Originally buried in St. Peter's Basilica ''sans'' monument in a red stone sarcophagus in the chapel of San Andrea; reinterred in an ancient sarcophagus in 1608, which was reopened two years later during the demolition;Reardon, 2004, p. 186. sometimes cited as buried in the Del Monte chapel of [[San Pietro in Montorio]] along with his adopted [[cardinal-nephew]], [[Innocenzo Ciocchi Del Monte]]Aldrich, Robert, and Wotherspoon, Garry. (2000). ''Who's Who in Gay and Lesbian History from Antiquity to World War II''. Routledge. {{ISBN|978-0-415-25369-7}}. p. 278. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| 1555–1555 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|[[File:Pope Marcellus II.jpg|70px]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Marcellus II|Marcellus II]]''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|No monument; fourth century sarcophagus, bearing a ''[[Christ in Majesty|traditio legis]]''Reardon, 2004, p. 187–188. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| 1572–1585 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|[[File:Gregory XIII.jpg|70px]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Gregory XIII|Gregory XIII]]''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|Original monument destroyed; new monument built in eighteenth centuryReardon, 2004, p. 195. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| 1590–1591 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|[[File:Gregory XIV.PNG|70px|]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Gregory XIV|Gregory XIV]]''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|Sculpted by [[Prospero Antichi]].Reardon, 2004, p. 199. |- valign="top" | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| 1591–1591 | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|[[File:Innocent9.jpg|70px]] | style="background:#c9c0bb;"| '''[[Pope Innocent IX|Innocent IX]]''' | style="background:#c9c0bb;"|No monument |} ==See also== * [[Index of Vatican City-related articles]] * [[Papal tombs]] * [[St. Peter's tomb]] == Notes == {{reflist|2}} == References == * {{citation | last = Gardner | first = Julian | title = The Tomb and the Tiara | publisher = Clarendon Press | location = Oxford | year = 1992 | isbn = 978-0-19-817510-0 }} * {{citation | last = Mann| first = H. K. | year = 2003| title =Tombs and Portraits of the Popes of the Middle Ages| publisher =Kessinger Publishing| isbn = 978-0-7661-2903-0}} * Reardon, Wendy J. 2004. ''The Deaths of the Popes''. Macfarland & Company, Inc. {{ISBN|978-0-7864-1527-4}} ==External links== * {{de icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20100127105000/http://www2.hu-berlin.de/requiem/ Information and images on papal tombs (1417 and 1799)] from the Requiem project {{Vatican City topics|state=collapsed}} {{coord|41.9022|N|12.4533|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} [[Category:Burial places of popes]] [[Category:Burials at St. Peter's Basilica|Old Saint Peters]] [[Category:Papal tombs]] [[Category:History of the papacy]] [[Category:Sarcophagi]]

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2009}} {{notability|date=November 2017}}
'''Pholage''' is an artistic technique and method of graphic reproduction invented by [[Manuel Bennett]] in 1959.
An extension of [[collage]], instead of consisting of mounting numerous pieces of colored paper or other material to make one original, pholage consists of taking positive or [[Negative (photography)|negative]] photographic film images, cutting out sections called "[[masks]]", and reassembling them to create a varied reproduction of the original. Additional drawings can be added to the color-separated original to further manipulate the original.
While collage yields a single piece of art, pholage can be reproduced by exposing photosensitive paper through the mask, or any other reproductive technique.
==See also== *[[Scanner art]] (scanner collage)
[[Category:Artistic techniques]] [[Category:Decorative arts]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|text=[[Pillow people]], the 1980s series of pillows which included pet designs}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox toy |name = Pillow Pets |image = [[File:Pillow Pets.jpg|220px]] |type = [[stuffed toy]] |inventor = Jennifer Telfer |country = United States |company = CJ Products |from = 2003 |to = present |materials = [[chenille fabric|chenille]] |slogan = It's a Pillow. It's a Pet... It's a Pillow Pet. |website = http://www.mypillowpets.com }}
'''Pillow Pets''' are a brand of [[stuffed toy]]s with [[Velcro]] straps that allow them to be changed from a decorated pillow into a stuffed animal. The toys are made from [[chenille fabric|chenille]]. Invented by Jennifer Telfer in 2003, Pillow Pets first gained success when Telfer personally sold the toys near the Christmas season of that year. They would later become more successful through [[television advertisement|television advertising]], where the company's famous slogan, "It's a pillow, it's a pet, it's a Pillow Pet!" was in every ad. Pillow Pets have been used for charitable fund raising.
==History== In 2003, Jennifer Telfer was living in San Diego<ref name="inventor">{{cite web | url=http://mypillowpets.com/about/message-from-the-founder/ | title=Pillow Pets Inventor | publisher=My Pillow Pets | accessdate=February 27, 2011}}</ref> with her husband, Clint, and two sons. In an interview with CNBC, Telfer states that she came up with the idea of functional stuffed toys when her oldest son, then seven, flattened out one of his stuffed animals from sleeping with it often.<ref name="CNBC">{{cite episode |title=Pillow Pets / Tate's Cookies / Tom's of Maine|series=How I Made My Millions | url=https://www.cnbc.com/video/2011/03/07/how-i-made-my-millions-episode-5.html | accessdate=January 26, 2018 | network=CNBC | airdate=March 2, 2011}}</ref> She decided on a combination of a pillow and a stuffed animal as the concept for Pillow Pets. Telfer and her husband proposed a meeting with a plush manufacturer at a [[trade fair|tradeshow]] in Las Vegas,<ref name="adage"/> and decided to wholesale the toys themselves through their company, CJ Products (CJ is a combination of their first initials).<ref name="inventor2"/> Following the meeting, the Telfers were prepared to sell the first toys.<ref name="adage">{{cite web |url= http://adage.com/article/print-edition/pillow-pets-america-s-hottest-brands-2010/147053/ |title= My Pillow Pets |author= Rooney, Jennifer |date= November 15, 2010 |work= Advertising Age |accessdate= March 6, 2011}}</ref>
The first Pillow Pet was "Snuggly Puppy".<ref name="adage"/> In the Christmas season, Jennifer Telfer first sold Pillow Pets at mall kiosks, but failed to sell them all: "Every single parent would walk up, and their kids would love them. [The parents would] say, 'No, it's just another stuffed animal.' Because they didn't know that it opened up to a pillow."<ref name="CNBC" /> A few weeks later, Telfer discovered that the Pillow Pets were most profitable during the period after Christmas when they were almost sold out at home shows. She later ordered a container of 7,000 Pillow Pets, now in six different animal varieties, and sold all of them in three months.<ref name="inventor2">{{cite web | url=http://mypillowpets.com/PillowPetsCEOBioFinal2.pdf | title=Jennifer Telfer Biography | publisher=My Pillow Pets | accessdate=April 26, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408192147/http://mypillowpets.com/PillowPetsCEOBioFinal2.pdf | archivedate=April 8, 2011 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> By the end of 2010, CJ Products earned $300,000 in [[gross (economics)|gross]] sales.<ref name="adage"/>
In 2009, CJ Products started using [[television advertisement|television advertising]] to promote the Pillow Pets. Commercials aired on children's cable channels such as Nickelodeon, and family-oriented networks such as Travel Channel.<ref name="adage"/> Partly because of the ads, gross sales of $7,000,000 were recorded at the end of 2009.<ref name="adage"/> Telfer recalled: "I didn't realize that we were gonna be at this level, or people would love my idea as much as I loved it."<ref name="CNBC" />
In 2012, Dream Lite Pillow Pets were introduced, along with Glow Pets in 2013.
==Product== [[File:Pillow Pet Dog.jpg|thumb|A "Snuggly Puppy" dog pillow pet]] An ordinary Pillow Pet is made with [[chenille fabric]].<ref name="about">{{cite web | url=http://mypillowpets.com/about/ | title=About Us | publisher=My Pillow Pets | accessdate=February 27, 2011}}</ref> Underneath it is a velcro strap. Given that it starts in pillow position, its strap fastens to the other side in order to transform it into a stuffed toy. If the strap is unfastened again, the Pillow Pet can again be used as a pillow.<ref name="about"/> The original release of Pillow Pets included merely six varieties.<ref>mypillowpetsreview.blogspot.com/2010/09/history-of-my-pillow-pets.html</ref> Now, more than one hundred varieties of Pillow Pets have been sold by CJ Products. Current varieties range from scented to body pillow pets, they even have a North Dakota State University pillow pet available as one of the licensed Pillow Pets.<ref>https://mypillowpets.com/shop/accessories/</ref> Available as one of the licensed Pillow Pets that exist for [[Major League Baseball|MLB]], [[National Football League|NFL]], [[National Hockey League|NHL]] and [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] sports teams.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://mypillowpets.com/shop/category/sports/ | title=Shop – Sports Teams | publisher=My Pillow Pets | accessdate=June 21, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110516105451/http://mypillowpets.com/shop/category/sports/ | archivedate=May 16, 2011 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> There are also themed Pillow Pets based on [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] characters.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://mypillowpets.com/shop/category/disney/ | title=Shop – Disney | publisher=My Pillow Pets | accessdate=October 24, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20111018112113/http://mypillowpets.com/shop/category/disney/ | archivedate=October 18, 2011 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> Stuffed toys based on [[Thomas the Tank Engine]], [[Scooby-Doo]], [[Dora the Explorer]], and [[SpongeBob SquarePants]] are being produced as well.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://mypillowpets.com/shop/category/specialty | title=Shop – Specialty | publisher=My Pillow Pets | accessdate=June 21, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20111022184444/http://mypillowpets.com/shop/category/specialty | archivedate=October 22, 2011 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> CJ Products has also licensed Pillow Pets for three [[Premier League|English Premier League]] football clubs for release in September.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.toynews-online.biz/news/36861/Arsenal-Chelsea-and-Spurs-Pillow-Pets-unveiled |title=Arsenal, Chelsea and Spurs Pillow Pets unveiled |publisher=Intent Media |work=ToyNews |date=August 6, 2012 |accessdate=August 16, 2012 |author=Sacco, Dominic}}</ref> Besides stuffed animals, other products bear the Pillow Pets name, such as blankets, slippers, hats, and print pajamas. Three Pillow Pets books and two board games are also available. In late October 2011, a Pillow Pets video game was released for [[Nintendo DS]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://wegotthiscovered.com/news/pillow-pets-nintendo-ds/ | title=Pillow Pets Is Now Available For Nintendo DS.}}</ref> Recently, Pillow Pets World online has been created, featuring interactive, Pillow Pet related games for children to play for free online.
==Charity work== CJ Products are known for their charity work, as they have donated Pillow Pets to many causes. In addition to CJ Products, the public have also donated Pillow Pets to help others.
===Indirect=== In December 2010, Michele McFarland, a human resources worker for the Baltimore County Department of Social Services, and her family, all from Catonsville, Maryland, started a Pillow Pet drive to help children at the [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]]. Their initial goal was to donate 200 toys, but they actually donated 250 Pillow Pets to the hospital in time for Christmas Eve. According to McFarland, residents of New York, New Jersey, Florida, and Georgia helped contribute.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.marylandfamilymagazine.com/2010/12/24/catonsville-family-leads-drive-to-donate-pillow-pets-to-childrens-center/ | title=Catonsville family leads drive to donate Pillow Pets to children’s center | work=Maryland Family Magazine | date=December 24, 2010 | accessdate=March 6, 2011 | author=Conlin, Brian | location=Catonsville, Maryland}}</ref> A year later, it was announced that McFarland aimed to donate even more Pillow Pets to five hospitals, including Johns Hopkins, by Christmas. She became affiliated with the Casey Cares Foundation and ordered 1,400 Pillow Pets to help the hospitals.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/explore/baltimorecounty/news/community/ph-ca-pillow-pets-1123-20111121,0,2872787.story | title=Catonsville woman aims to comfort children not just during holidays | publisher=Tribune Company | work=Baltimore Sun | date=November 21, 2011 | accessdate=November 22, 2011 | author=Conlin, Brian}}</ref>
Jacob McConahay (then seven) and his family accepted donations of Pillow Pets in the [[James Whitcomb Riley Hospital for Children|Riley Hospital for Children]], in [[Indianapolis]], where Jacob was diagnosed with an aggressive form of cancer. An early childhood volunteer mentioned that Jacob's goal was 1,000 Pillow Pets.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://newsfromyou.indystar.com/posts/cancer-doesn-t-hold-jake-back-from-collecting-pillow-pets | title=Cancer doesn't hold Jake back from collecting Pillow Pets | work=The Indianopolis Star | date=February 7, 2011 | accessdate=March 5, 2011 | author=Welty, Lauren | location=Indianopolis, Indiana | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120711192602/http://newsfromyou.indystar.com/posts/cancer-doesn-t-hold-jake-back-from-collecting-pillow-pets | archivedate=July 11, 2012 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> CJ Products had heard about Jacob's goal, and they committed to matching the number of Pillow Pets that he collected.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://mypillowpetsblog.com/help-support-pillow-pets%e2%84%a2-for-jacob/ | title=Help Support Pillow Pets for Jacob | publisher=My Pillow Pets Blog | date=March 9, 2011 | accessdate=March 12, 2011}}</ref> McConahay's wish to help children in the Riley Hospital inspired students at China Grove Middle School in North Carolina to donate Pillow Pets to patients at the Jeff Gordon Children's Hospital.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.salisburypost.com/News/041411-edu-MUST-China-Grove-pillow-pets-PIC-qcd | title=School collects Pillow Pets for Jeff Gordon’s Children’s Hospital | publisher=Post Publishing Company | work=The Salisbury Post | date=April 14, 2011 | accessdate=November 19, 2011}}</ref> Jacob died on August 31, 2011. {{as of|November 2011}} his family has collected over 140,000 Pillow Pets in his name.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://dunedin.patch.com/articles/pillow-pets-to-honor-young-cancer-victim | title=Pillow Pets, Vigil to Honor Late 7-Year-Old | publisher=DunedinPatch | date=November 17, 2011 | accessdate=November 17, 2011 | author=Dolac, Katie}}</ref>
===Direct=== Following the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]] in Japan, CJ Products, [[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]], and the [[American Red Cross]], collaborated to support relief efforts. Pillow Pets announced that they would donate one dollar of every purchase of a Pillow Pet on their website, on March 17 and 18, 2011, to the American Red Cross. They also auctioned five Pillow Pets on the same days, and the money also went to the American Red Cross.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://mypillowpetsblog.com/support-relief-efforts-in-japan-with-pillow-pets-plush-animals-the-today-show-the-american-red-cross/ | title=Support Relief Efforts in Japan with Pillow Pets plush animals, The Today Show & the American Red Cross | publisher=My Pillow Pets Blog | date=March 17, 2011 | accessdate=March 18, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120714001541/http://mypillowpetsblog.com/support-relief-efforts-in-japan-with-pillow-pets-plush-animals-the-today-show-the-american-red-cross/ | archivedate=July 14, 2012 | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Since 2008, Pillow Pets has collaborated with the Family Reach Foundation to help families of children to fight cancer. In September 2011, the foundation received a donation of 6,200 Pillow Pets and was able to generate thousands of dollars in funds. Carla Tardif, the Foundations' director of development and special programs, stated a consideration of initiatives to create more promotion of Family Reach's cause and raise charitable funds for families worldwide. "We applaud the tremendous amount of work being done by the Family Reach Foundation on behalf of [the] families," Jennifer Telfer said.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.familyreach.org/news/family-reach-receives-major-donation-of-pillow-pets%E2%84%A2/ | title=Family Reach Receives Major Donation of Pillow Pets to Support its Mission | publisher=Family Reach Foundation | date=September 28, 2011 | accessdate=November 20, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426085418/http://www.familyreach.org/news/family-reach-receives-major-donation-of-pillow-pets%E2%84%A2/ | archivedate=April 26, 2012 | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Counterfeits== Some toy companies have taken advantage of Pillow Pets' popularity by manufacturing and selling counterfeits. CJ Products have been notified many times of impostor Pillow Pets.<ref>{{cite press_release | url=http://mypillowpets.com/HOLIDAYSHOPPERS-BEWAREOFPILLOWPETS%20IMPOSTORS12-21-10.pdf | title=Holiday Shoppers: Beware of Pillow Pets Impostors | date=December 21, 2009 | accessdate=March 6, 2011}}</ref> Telfer said: "It is priority one for us to protect our brand and deliver the high quality people have come to expect when they see the My Pillow Pets plush folding stuffed animals authentic tag."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.pets4home.net/consumers-help-combat-my-pillow-pets-plush-folding-stuffed-animal-fraud/ | title=Consumers Help Combat My Pillow Pets Plush Folding Stuffed Animal Fraud | publisher=Pets 4 Home | date=September 7, 2010 | accessdate=November 19, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303224152/http://www.pets4home.net/consumers-help-combat-my-pillow-pets-plush-folding-stuffed-animal-fraud/ | archivedate=March 3, 2016 | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In one case, in January 2011, Concord Toys International were accused of selling fake Pillow Pets. Their products were being sold in a warehouse in Queens, New York City and bore the label "[[Made in China]]." Private detectives hired by CJ Products tracked the toys to the warehouse, where U.S. marshals seized 17,000 counterfeits. An injunction was signed preventing Concord from manufacturing any forgeries, and CJ Products are seeking punitive damages against the company.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2011-01-25/news/27096545_1_pillow-pets-federal-court-lawyers | title=Fake Thumpy, Squeaky in custody as lawyers for Pillow Pets seek damages for counterfeit items | work=New York Daily News | date=January 25, 2011 | accessdate=March 5, 2011 | author=Marzulli, John}}</ref>
==Awards and accolades== Pillow Pets have won several awards for being a child-friendly product. In 2009, Stevanne Auerbach recognized the toy as one of the Best Vacation Toys.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.drtoy.com/product-view/?productid=1159 | title=CJ Products – My Pillow Pets | publisher=Dr. Toy | accessdate=March 6, 2011 | author=Auerbach, Stevanne}}</ref> Also in 2009, [[Armin Brott]] of Mr. Dad awarded the product the Mr. Dad Seal of Approval for Father's Day.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mrdad.com/seal/winners-06-09.htm | title=Mr. Dad Seal of Approval Recipients for Father's Day 2009 | publisher=Mr. Dad | accessdate=March 6, 2011 | author=Brott, Armin | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120905022011/http://www.mrdad.com/seal/winners-06-09.htm | archivedate=September 5, 2012 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> Pillow Pets were among toys on [[Toys R Us]]'s 2010 'Hot Toy' list.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.ohio.com/business/cute-collectible-toys-top-toys-r-us-hot-list-1.174871 | title=Cute and Collectible Top Toys R Us 'Hot Toy' List | publisher=Ohio.com | date=September 26, 2010 | agency=Associated Press | accessdate=June 21, 2011 | author=Anderson, Mae}}</ref>

{{For|the United States Navy ship|USS Pomander (SP-702)}} [[File:Pomander 3.jpg|thumb|Venetian woman with a pomander]] A pomander, from [[French language|French]] ''pomme d'ambre'', i.e., apple of amber, is a ball made for perfumes, such as [[ambergris]] (whence the name), [[musk]], or [[civet (perfumery)|civet]].{{sfn|Chisholm|1911|p=46}} The pomander was worn or carried in a vase, also known by the same name, as a protection against [[infection]] in times of pestilence or merely as a useful article to modify bad smells.{{sfn|Chisholm|1911|p=46}} The globular cases which contained the pomanders were hung from a neck-chain or belt, or attached to the girdle, and were usually perforated in a variety of [[openwork]] techniques, and made of gold or silver.{{sfn|Chisholm|1911|p=46}} Sometimes they contained several partitions, in each of which was placed a different perfume.{{sfn|Chisholm|1911|p=46}} The term "pomander" can refer to the scented material itself or to the container that which contains such material.{{cite web|url=http://www.larsdatter.com/pomanders.htm|title=Pomanders|work=larsdatter.com}}[http://www.silvercollection.it/dictionarypomander.html POMANDER MEMENTO MORI]Corine Schleif and Volker Schier, ''Katerina's Windows: Donation and Devotion, Art and Music, as Heard and Seen Through the Writings of a Birgittine Nun,'' University Park: Penn State Press, 2009, pp. 237, 242-244 The container could be made of gold or silver and eventually evolved to be shaped like nuts, skulls, hearts, books and ships. Smaller versions were made to be attached by a chain to a finger ring and held in the hand. Even smaller versions served as cape buttons or rosary beads.{{cite web|url=https://www.ganoksin.com/article/small-wonders-aromatic-adornments/|title=Small Wonders – Aromatic Adornments|publisher= ganoskin|accessdate= 12 March 2017}} A pomander can be a bag containing fragrant herbs and might be viewed as an early form of [[aromatherapy]]. Pomanders can be considered related to [[censer]]s, in which aromatics are burned or roasted rather than naturally evaporated. ==History== Pomanders were first mentioned in literature in the mid-thirteenth century.{{cite web|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/bulletin_of_hispanic_studies/v086/86.1.twomey.html|title=Project MUSE - The Bulletin of Hispanic Studies - Perfumes and perfume-making in the Celestina|work=jhu.edu}} They were used in the late [[Middle Ages]] through the 17th century.Groom, p. 274 Also a version of the pomander with oranges, [[clove]]s, oils, and a golden ribbon can be used as a recovery charm in witchcraft.{{cite web|url=http://hearth-n-home.blogspot.com/2011/12/pomander-recovery-spell-and-charm.html|title=Hearth-n-Home: Pomander Recovery spell and charm|author=Mamma Kay|work=hearth-n-home.blogspot.com}}{{cite web|url=http://begumafreedaali.blogspot.com/2013/08/a-magical-pomander.html|title=A-Magical Pomander ~ Begum Afreeda Ali|work=begumafreedaali.blogspot.com}}{{cite web|url=http://witcheslore.com/bookofshadows/rituals-spell-casting/magic-and-spell-casting/2537/|title=Magic and Spell-Casting - Witchcraft - Pagan, Wiccan, Occult and Magick|work=witcheslore.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.spellsofmagic.com/coven_spells.html?coven=6&slist=7|title=Cure Spells|work=SpellsOfMagic}} ===Medieval=== Pomanders were first made for carrying as religious keepsakes.[http://www.guyotbrothers.com/jewelry-history/jewelry-history-page11.htm Jewelry of the middle ages] ===Renaissance=== The ''Archaeological Journal'', Volume 31 of 1874 describes on page 339 a 1584 formula for making a pomander that was also published by [[Frederic Madden]] in his 1831 history book ''Privy purse expenses of the Princess Mary, daughter of [[King Henry the Eighth]], afterwards [[Mary I of England|Queen Mary]]'' on page 257: {{Quote|[[Benzoin resin]], [[calamite]], [[labdanum]], and [[storax balsam]] were ground into a powder, dissolved in [[rose water]] and put into a pan over a fire to cook together. The cooked mixture was then removed from the fire, rolled into an apple shape and coated with a powdered mixture of cinnamon, sweet sanders, and cloves. After this, a concoction was made from three grains each of [[ambergris]], [[deer musk]], and [[civet (perfumery)|civet musk]]. The ambergris was dissolved first and the deer and civet musk mixed in later. The "apple" ball was rolled through the musk concoction to blend in these ingredients and then kneaded to combine and molded back into the shape of an apple.Longman, p. 339Madden, p. 257}} ====Nostradamus==== [[Michel de Nostredame]] had a similar method and formula using similar ingredients, but a rather different procedure. "Rose tablets" were made by soaking a pound of roses without the flower heads in [[deer musk]] water overnight. The water was then thoroughly squeezed out and the roses ground with seven ounces of [[benzoin resin|benzoin]], a quarter of [[ambergris]] and another of [[civet (perfumery)|civet musk]]. This mixture was made into tablets, which were each sandwiched between rose petals and dried in a cool, dark areaBoeser (chapter 11) To form the final pomander, two ounces of the purest [[labdanum]], an ounce each of [[Styrax]] calamites and benzoin resin, half an ounce of the rose tablets, one ounce of violet powder, and half a [[dram (unit)|dram]] each ambergris and musk were ground into a powder and kneaded with the rose-musk water from the production of the rose tablets. This produced "an aromatic ball of the most supreme perfume, and the longest-lasting that can be made anywhere in the world." ====Pouncet box==== In the late 16th century the pouncet box appeared which, whilst retaining the traditional features of the pomander, was designed to hold liquid perfumes, blended with powder and absorbed on a sponge or piece of cotton. It was favoured by the upper classes who appreciated the delicacy of the liquid perfumes. Its name stemmed from the fact that the box was "pounced" or pierced to release the scent.{{cite web|url=https://www.ganoksin.com/article/small-wonders-aromatic-adornments/|title=Small Wonders – Aromatic Adornments|publisher=Ganoskin|accessdate=12 March 2017}} ===Modern=== [[File:Orange pomander.jpg|thumb|An orange studded with [[clove]]s.]] One modern style of pomander is made by studding an orange or other fruit with whole dried [[clove]]s and letting it [[curing (food preservation)|cure dry]], after which it may last several years. This modern pomander serves the functions of perfuming and freshening the air and also of keeping drawers of clothing and linens fresh, pleasant-smelling, and moth-free. ==Ingredients== Other ingredients in the process of making pomanders are: *[[Agarwood]] *[[Ambergris]] *[[Benzoin resin]] *[[Acorus calamus|Calamus]] *[[Camphor]] *[[Cinnamon]] *[[Civet (perfumery)]] *[[Clove]]s *[[Gum arabic]] *[[Labdanum]] *[[Lavender]] *[[Mace (spice)|Mace]] *[[Marjoram]] *[[Musk]] *[[Nutmeg]] *[[Orris root]] *[[Rose oil]] *[[Rosemary]] *[[Scented water]] *[[Spikenard]] *[[Styrax]] *[[Tragacanth]] *[[Elsholtzia ciliata|Vietnamese Balm]] ==Culture== A pomander is worn by [[Mia Farrow|Rosemary Woodhouse]], in [[Roman Polanski]]'s 1968 film, ''[[Rosemary's Baby (film)|Rosemary's Baby]]''. It figures as a central part of the plot development. The pouncet box is mentioned in Shakespeare's ''[[Henry IV Part I]]'' when Hotspur is accused of withholding Scottish nobles captured in a skirmish and in self-defence pleads, in describing the King's messenger:
::He was perfumèd like a milliner, ::And ’twixt his finger and his thumb he held ::A pouncet box, which ever and anon ::He gave his nose and took’t away again, ::Who therewith angry, when it next came there, ::Took it in snuff; and still he smiled and talked.
==Etymology== Medieval pomander paste formulas usually contained ambergris. From this came "pomme ambre" (amber apple) and from there the word ''pomander'' was developed. Other names for the pomander are Ambraapfel, Bisamapfel, Bisamknopf, Bisambüchse, balsam apple, Desmerknopf, musk ball Desmerapfel, Oldanokapsel, Pisambüchse, and smelling apple. ==See also== *[[Sachet]] (scented bag) ==Gallery==
File:Pomander 1518.jpg|[[Jacob Cornelisz van Oostsanen]], Pomander, c. 1518 (Portrait of Jan Gerritz van Egmond van de Dijenborgh, elected Burgomaster of Alkmaar detail) File:Global and box pomander.jpg|Global and box pomander File:Hollar-Dürer Pomander.png|Design for a pomander by [[Wenzel Hollar]] File:Rosary with pomander.jpg|[[Barthel Bruyn the Elder]], Rosary with pomander (Diptych with portraits of the Pilgrum couple (left side: [[Gerhard Pilgrum]]) detail) File:Amberger - Portrait of a man.jpg|[[Christoph Amberger]], ''Portrait of a Man'' (c. 1534–1566) File:Pourbus lady pomander.jpg|[[Pieter Pourbus|Pourbus]], an unknown lady, holding a pomander on a gold chain (c. 1560–1565) File:Barthel Bruyn 2.jpg|[[Barthel Bruyn the Elder]], portrait of a woman, c. 1538 File:European - Pomander in the Shape of a Ship - Walters 44464 - Profile.jpg|Pomander in the shape of a ship, c. 1600–1650, [[Walters Art Museum]]
==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== *Boeser, Knut, ''The elixirs of Nostradamus: Nostradamus' original recipes for elixirs, scented water, beauty potions, and sweetmeats'', Moyer Bell, 1996; {{ISBN|1-55921-155-5}} *Groom, Nigel, ''The new perfume handbook,'' Springer, 1997, {{ISBN|0-7514-0403-9}} *Longman, Rrown, ''The Archaeological journal,'' Volume 31, Green and Longman 1874 *Madden, Frederic, ''Privy purse expenses of the Princess Mary, daughter of King Henry the Eighth, afterwards Queen Mary'', W. Pickering 1831 *[[Corine Schleif|Schleif, Corine]] and Volker Schier, '' Katerina's Windows: Donation and Devotion, Art and Music, as Heard and Seen Through the Writings of a Birgittine Nun,'' University Park: Penn State Press, 2009, 237, 242-244, {{ISBN|978-0-271-03369-3}} ;Attribution *{{EB1911|wstitle=Pomander|volume=22|page=46}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Pomanders}} {{Wiktionary}} *[http://wwwg.uni-klu.ac.at/kultdoku/kataloge/14/html/1191.htm Bisamapfel] detailed function of medieval pomander in German. Use Google Translate for English. *[http://www.larsdatter.com/pomanders.htm Medieval & Renaissance Pomanders] 14th-17th century pomanders in museums *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090423064618/http://www.wartski.com/Pomander.htm 17th century pomander Wartski, London] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100827081419/http://www.pioneerthinking.com/pomanders.html How To Make Pomanders] *[http://www.pomanderwatch.com/clocks/pomander-watches/ Watches in Pomanders from 1500 to 1550] *[http://www.peterhenlein.com Peter Henlein: Pomander Watch Anno 1505] {{Perfume}} [[Category:Perfumery]]
