revision.comment: /* VW/Dieselgate apology */ April 2018 Houston Art Car Parade entry; Houston Chronicle gets pranked
revision.text:
{{About|the culture-jamming activists|this group's 2003 documentary of the same name|The Yes Men (film)|other things with similar titles|Yes man (disambiguation)}} {{Anti-consumerism|Organizations}} [[File:The Yes Men at re-publica 2014.jpg|thumb|The Yes Men at [[re:publica|re:publica 2014]]]]
'''The Yes Men''' are a [[culture jamming]] activist duo and network of supporters created by [[Jacques Servin]] and [[Igor Vamos]].<ref name="chron.com">{{cite web|last=Britt |first=Douglas |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ent/6983925.html |title=The Yes Men infiltrate DiverseWorks |publisher=Houston Chronicle |date=April 30, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2010}}</ref> Through actions of [[tactical media]],{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} the Yes Men primarily aim to raise awareness about problematic social and political issues. To date, the duo have produced three films: ''[[The Yes Men (film)|The Yes Men]]'' (2003), ''[[The Yes Men Fix the World]]'' (2009)<ref name="chron.com"/> and ''[[The Yes Men Are Revolting]]'' (2014). In these films, they impersonate entities that they dislike, a practice that they call "identity correction". The Yes Men operate under the mission statement that lies can expose truth. They create and maintain fake websites similar to ones they intend to spoof, which have led to numerous interview, conference, and TV talk show invitations. They espouse the belief that [[corporation]]s and governmental organizations often act in [[dehumanizing]] ways toward the public. Elaborate props are sometimes part of the ruse (e.g. [[The Yes Men#New York Post and SurvivaBall|Survivaball]]), as shown in their 2003 DVD release ''The Yes Men''. The Yes Men have collaborated with other groups of similar interest, including [[Improv Everywhere]], Andrew Boyd and [[Steve Lambert]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theyesmen.org/ |title=The Yes Men |publisher=The Yes Men |date= |accessdate=August 2, 2010}}</ref>
== Background == According to Servin, the Yes Men concept initially sprang from their creation of a fake website spoofing the [[World Trade Organization]]. To the surprise of Servin and Vamos, many believed the site to be authentic, and the two were consequently contacted to speak at a conference in Austria. Since this time, the Yes Men have continued performing large-scale hoaxes, in what they describe as a collaborative effort with journalists to help the media tell stories which they believe are important.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s6fay3RNXI8 |title=The Yes Men Fix the World's Andy Bichlbaum on How The Yes Men Got Started |publisher=YouTube |date=September 28, 2009|accessdate=August 2, 2010}}</ref>
The Yes Men often deploy a satirical approach: they pose as a powerful entity (typically a corporate or government representative or executive) and make ridiculous and shocking comments that caricature the ideological position of the organisation or person. Furthermore, they acknowledge the idea that many corporate or government entities manipulate their ideology using [[Spin (public relations)|spin]]; in response, the Yes Men use this power of spin to their own advantage, and use media outlets to disseminate their personal interpretation of the situation. A sense of humor and shock value is usually employed to make these issues more palatable to the general public and to call greater media attention to stories of interest.<ref name="chron.com"/> Some of these outrageous ideas include the prospect of selling one's vote or a proposition that the poor should consume recycled human waste. On most occasions, little to no shock or outrage is publicly evoked in response to their prank.
On occasion, the Yes Men's phony spokesperson will make announcements that represent fictitious scenarios for the [[anti-globalization movement]] or opponents of [[corporate crime]]. This has often resulted in false news reports, such as those covering the demise of the [[World Trade Organization]], or [[Dow Chemical]] paying compensation to the victims of the [[Bhopal disaster]].
The Yes Men have posed as spokespeople for the WTO, [[McDonald's]], Dow Chemical, and the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development]]. The two leading members of the Yes Men are known by a number of aliases, most recently, and in film, [[Andy Bichlbaum]] and [[Mike Bonanno]] ([[Jacques Servin]]<ref name="simcopter">{{cite news | url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/1996-12-08/news/18024496_1_simcopter-helicopter-simulation-game-maxis | title=PIXEL GAIETY COSTS JOB | publisher=[[Daily News (New York)]] | date=1996-12-08 | accessdate=May 30, 2012}}</ref> and [[Igor Vamos]], respectively). Servin is an author of experimental fiction, and was known for being the man who inserted images of men kissing in the computer game ''[[SimCopter]]''. Vamos is an associate professor of media arts at [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]], New York. They are assisted by numerous people across the globe. There are other full-time members, such as Whitney Black and Rocco Ferrer, who take a more behind-the-scenes approach.
Their experiences were documented in the film ''The Yes Men'',<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0379593/ The Yes Men (2003)] IMDB.com</ref> distributed by United Artists, the film documentary ''[[info wars]]'', and the book ''[[The Yes Men: The True Story of the End of the World Trade Organization]]'' ({{ISBN|0-9729529-9-3}}). Andy Bichlbaum and Mike Bonanno also directed a [[2009 in film|2009]] film entitled ''[[The Yes Men Fix the World]]'', which premiered at the [[Sundance Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://theyesmenfixtheworld.com/index.htm |title=NOW AVAILABLE ON DVD - THE YES MEN FIX THE WORLD - The new movie that exposes the world of big business and the outrageous pranks that highlight the ways that corporate greed is destroying the planet. Featuring Andy Bichlbaum and Mike Bonanno |publisher=The Yes Men Fix The World |date= |accessdate=2010-08-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zBy9uyca?url=http://theyesmenfixtheworld.com/index.htm |archivedate=2011-06-04 |df= }}</ref> In 2009 they launched their online video channel on [[Babelgum]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.babelgum.com/yesmen |title=Yes Men |publisher=Babelgum |date= |accessdate=2010-08-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zByDXrmq?url=http://www.babelgum.com/yesmen |archivedate=2011-06-04 |df= }}</ref>
Their third film, ''[[The Yes Men Are Revolting]]'', premiered at the [[2014 Toronto International Film Festival]].
== Projects ==
=== George W. Bush === One of the Yes Men's first pranks was the satirical website www.gwbush.com, established for the [[2000 US presidential election]] to draw attention to alleged hypocrisies on Bush's actual website. When asked about the site in a press conference on May 21, 1999, Bush responded that the website had gone too far in criticizing him.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/WPcap/1999-11/29/002r-112999-idx.html |title=Satirical Web Site Poses Political Test |first=Terry M. |last=Neal |publisher=The Washington Post |date=November 29, 1999}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.rtmark.com/more/articles/bushdallas0522bush1bushsite.htm | title=Bush criticizes Web site as malicious | publisher=The Dallas Morning News | date=May 22, 1999 | accessdate=May 30, 2012 | last=Slater | first=Wayne | deadurl=bot: unknown | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120911165539/http://www.rtmark.com/more/articles/bushdallas0522bush1bushsite.htm | archivedate=September 11, 2012 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theyesmen.org/hijinks/bush/ |title=The Yes Men: Bush |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69TEbgvxn?url=http://theyesmen.org/hijinks/bush |archivedate=2012-07-27 |df= }}</ref>
In 2004, the Yes Men went on tour posing as the group "Yes, Bush Can!" and encouraged supporters to sign a "Patriot Pledge" agreeing to keep [[nuclear waste]] in their back yards and send their children off to war. They appeared at the [[2004 Republican National Convention]] and drove across the country at first in an RV with a George W. Bush body wrap, and then in a painted van.
==== Ice Age Petition ==== The Yes Men posed as working as part of the [[George W. Bush presidential campaign, 2004|Bush-Cheney campaign]]. They carried around a petition asking for signatures to support [[global warming]] because America's competing countries will suffer while America only bears minor side effects.<ref>{{cite web |title= The Yes Men on Ice Age Petition |publisher=YouTube |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P_kqsuOxKFY}}</ref>
=== Dow Chemical === <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Dow apologizes.jpg|left|thumb|Andy Bichlbaum, a member of the Yes Men, appears on [[BBC World]] to take full responsibility for the [[Bhopal disaster]].]] -->
On December 3, 2004, the twentieth anniversary of the [[Bhopal disaster]], Andy Bichlbaum appeared on [[BBC World]] as "Jude Finisterra",<ref>{{cite news|title="The Yes Men Fix the World": In New Film, Anti-Corporate Pranksters the Yes Men Continue to Jolt Polluters and Profiteers|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2009/7/23/yes_men|accessdate=2010-12-04|newspaper=Democracy Now!|date=July 23, 2009|first=Mike |last=Bonanno|first2=Andy |last2=Bichlbaum|first3=Juan |last3=Gonzalez|quote= ANDY BICHLBAUM: Well, Jude is the patron saint of the impossible, and there’s absolutely no way a company like Dow will ever do the right thing in Bhopal, unless we force it. And Finisterra, of course, end of the world, end of the earth. It’s just never going to happen. }}</ref> a [[Dow Chemical Company|Dow Chemical]] spokesman.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LiWlvBro9eI |title=YouTube: Bhopal Disaster - BBC - The Yes Men |publisher=BBC World News}}</ref> Dow is the owner of [[Union Carbide]], the company responsible for the chemical disaster in Bhopal, India on December 3, 1984. An estimated 3,800 people died immediately from the hazardous chemicals and thousands more were killed by the plume from the UCC plant during the next few days.<ref name="Fortun">{{cite book |last=Fortun |first=K |title=Advocacy after Bhopal |location=Chicago |publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=2001 |page=259}}</ref> The Indian government reported that more than half a million people were exposed to the gas, leading to numerous early and late health defects.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Cassells |first=J |title=Sovereign immunity: Law in an unequal world |journal=Social and legal studies |year=1996 |volume=5 |issue=3 |pages=431–436}}</ref> The Bhopal Disaster became one of the worst chemical disasters in history and the name Bhopal became synonymous with industrial catastrophe.<ref>{{cite journal |last=MacKenzie |first=D |title=Fresh evidence on Bhopal disaster |journal=New Scientist |year=2002 |volume=19 |issue=1}}</ref> Immediately after the disaster, UCC began attempts to dissociate itself from responsibility for the gas leak.<ref name="Fortun"/> The Indian Supreme Court eventually mediated a settlement in which UCC accepted moral responsibility and agreed to pay $470 million to the Indian government to be distributed to claimants as a full and final settlement. The average amount to families of the dead was $2,200.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Kumar |first=S |title=Victims of gas leak in Bhopal seek redress on compensation |journal=BMJ |year=2004 |volume=329 |issue=7462 |page=366 |doi=10.1136/bmj.329.7462.366-b |pmid=15310593 |pmc=509368}}</ref>
On their fake Dow Chemical website, the Yes Men said that Dow Chemical Company had no intention whatsoever of repairing the damage.<ref>{{cite web |title=Dow Ethics website |url=http://www.dowethics.com/}}</ref> The real company received considerable backlash, and both the real Dow and the phony Dow denied the statements, but Dow took no real action.
The Yes Men decided to pressure Dow further, so as "Finisterra," Bichlbaum went on the news to claim that Dow planned to liquidate Union Carbide and use the resulting $12 billion to pay for medical care, clean up the site, and fund research into the hazards of other Dow products. After two hours of wide coverage, Dow issued a press release denying the statement, ensuring even greater coverage of the phony news of a cleanup. In Frankfurt, Dow's share price fell 4.24 percent in 23 minutes, wiping $2 billion off its market value. The shares rebounded in Frankfurt after the BBC issued an on-air correction and apology. In New York, Dow Chemical's stock were little changed because of the early trading.<ref name="CNNWorld">{{cite news | url=http://articles.cnn.com/2004-12-03/world/bhopal.hoax_1_dow-chemical-dow-stock-bhopal?_s=PM:WORLD | title=Bhopal hoax sends Dow stock down | work=CNN.com | date=December 3, 2004 | accessdate=May 30, 2012}}</ref>
After the original interview was revealed as a hoax, Bichlbaum appeared in a follow-up interview on the United Kingdom's Channel 4 news.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.babelgum.com/4024557/yes-men-the-legendary-bbc-bhopal-hoax.html |title=Yes Men: The legendary BBC Bhopal Hoax |publisher=Babelgum.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607150127/http://www.babelgum.com/4024557/yes-men-the-legendary-bbc-bhopal-hoax.html |archivedate=2010-06-07 |df= }}</ref> During the interview he was asked if he had considered the emotions and reaction of the people of Bhopal when producing the hoax. According to the interviewer, "there were many people in tears" upon having learned of the hoax. Bichlbaum said that, in comparison, what distress he had caused the people was minimal to that for which Dow was responsible. The Yes Men claim on their website that they have been told by contacts in Bhopal that once they had got over their disappointment that it wasn't real, they were pleased about the stunt and thought it had helped to raise awareness of their plight.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theyesmen.org/faq#falsehopes |title=Frequently Asked Questions |publisher=The Yes Men |date=2010-04-01 |accessdate=2010-08-02}}</ref>
At the [[International Payments Conference]] on April 28, 2005, 'Dow representative' "Erastus Hamm" unveiled Acceptable Risk, the Acceptable Risk Calculator, and the Acceptable Risk mascot — a life-sized golden skeleton named Gilda — to an audience of about 70 banking professionals.
In February 2012, it was widely reported in the [[2012 Stratfor email leak]] that Dow Chemical Company hired private intelligence firm [[Stratfor]] to monitor the Yes Men.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Stratfor-was-Dows-Bhopal-spy-WikiLeaks/articleshow/12062587.cms |title=Stratfor was Dow’s Bhopal spy: WikiLeaks |publisher=[[The Times of India]] |date=February 28, 2012 |accessdate=February 28, 2012}}</ref>
=== WTO === One of the Yes Men's most famous pranks is placing a "corrected" [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] website at http://www.gatt.org/ ([[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade]]). The fake site began to receive real emails from confused visitors, including invitations to address various elite groups on behalf of the WTO, to which they responded as if they were the actual WTO. {{Citation needed|date=March 2016}}
Appearing in newly purchased suits, the Yes Men gave speeches encouraging corporations to buy votes directly from citizens. They argued that the US Civil War was a waste of money because Third World countries now willingly supply equivalent slaves. They also urged people to listen to the WTO instead of the facts. They then unveiled a gold spandex body suit that they claimed would allow productivity to increase, as managers would not have to oversee workers in person but could keep track of them via images on an attached screen as well as implanted sensors. {{Citation needed|date=March 2016}}
=== New Orleans and HUD === {{Wikinews|HUD hoaxer calls attention to lack of affordable housing}} The Yes Men appeared on August 28, 2006 at a "Housing Summit" in New Orleans, taking the stage along with New Orleans Mayor [[Ray Nagin]] and Louisiana Governor [[Kathleen Blanco]]. Before an audience composed mostly of real estate developers, one of the Yes Men gave a speech in which he claimed to be Rene Oswin, a fictitious "assistant under-secretary" at the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development]] (HUD). In his speech he claimed that HUD would reopen public housing facilities that had been closed since [[Hurricane Katrina]] struck in August 2005. He announced this false claim because HUD had recently decided to only rebuild a third of the subsidized housing stock after hurricane Katrina, and made plans to demolish four of New Orleans’ ten public housing developments, leaving thousands of New Orleans residents without homes. This decision was contested locally, nationally, and internationally.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Luft |first=Rachel E. |title=Looking For Common Ground: Relief Work In Post-Katrina New Orleans As An American Parable Of Race And Gender Violence |journal=NWSA Journal |volume=20 |issue=3 |year=2008 |pages=5–31}}</ref> So, the Yes Men proclaimed that HUD had changed its mind about tearing down the undamaged housing units, and would not tear down the housing projects, as they had planned to do in order to replace them with mixed-income developments.<ref>{{Cite news |title= Oops: Impostor scams Louisiana officials |url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/POLITICS/08/28/hud.hoax/index.html |date=2006-08-28 |publisher=CNN}}</ref>
HUD has called this prank, which brought attention to the lack of affordable housing,{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} a "cruel hoax." A former resident of the community was quoted by Bichlbaum as saying, "do whatever's most effective, do it, don't worry about how it affects us," however.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2006/08/29/yes_men |title=The HUD Hoax |first=Alex |last=Koppelman |publisher=Salon |date=August 29, 2006}}</ref> HUD spokeswoman Donna White said no one named "Rene Oswin" works for the department. White commented, "I'm like, who the heck is that?"<ref>{{cite news | url=http://tpmmuckraker.talkingpointsmemo.com/2006/08/fake_hud_official_punkd_louisi.php | title=Fake HUD Official Punk'd Louisiana Pols | work=TPM Muckraker | date=August 28, 2006 | accessdate=May 30, 2012 | last=Rood | first=Justin}}</ref>
The fictitious Oswin also announced that the big oil companies would contribute some of their record profits to rebuild the wetlands destroyed by the construction of oil tanker canals to prevent the city from being inundated by future hurricanes.
=== ExxonMobil === [[Image:The Yes Men.jpg|thumb|[[Andy Bichlbaum]] and [[Mike Bonanno]] pose as [[ExxonMobil]] executives.]] On June 14, 2007, the Yes Men acted during [[Canada]]'s largest oil conference in [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], posing as [[ExxonMobil]] and [[National Petroleum Council (US)|National Petroleum Council]] (NPC) representatives. In front of more than 300 oilmen, the NPC was expected to deliver the long-awaited conclusions of a study commissioned by [[United States Secretary of Energy|U.S. Energy Secretary]] [[Samuel Bodman]]. The NPC is headed by former ExxonMobil CEO [[Lee Raymond]], who is also the chair of the study.<ref>{{cite web |title=What's At Stake? Don't Let Exxon Decide Our Energy future! |url=http://ga3.org/campaign/lee_raymond/explanation |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061102073241/http://ga3.org/campaign/lee_raymond/explanation |archivedate=2006-11-02 |publisher=The Exxpose Exxon campaign}}</ref> When the Yes Men arrived at the conference they said that [[Lee Raymond]] (the promised speaker) was unable to make it due to a pressing situation with the president. The Yes Men then went on to give a presentation in place of Lee Raymond.
In the actual speech, the "NPC rep" announced that current U.S. and Canadian energy policies (notably the massive, carbon-intensive processing of [[Alberta's oil sands]], and the development of [[liquid coal]]) are increasing the chances of huge global calamities. But he reassured the audience that in the worst-case scenario, the oil industry could "keep fuel flowing" by transforming the billions of people who would die into oil.<ref>{{Cite press release |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/WO0706/S00281.htm |title=Exxon Proposes Burning Humanity for Fuel |publisher=The Yes Men |date=June 15, 2007}}</ref>
The project, called '''Vivoleum''', would work in perfect synergy with the continued expansion of fossil fuel production. The oilmen listened to the lecture with attention, and then lit "commemorative candles". At this point, event security recognized the Yes Men and forced them off stage, and the 'punchline' — that the candles were made of Vivoleum obtained from the flesh of an "Exxon janitor" who died as a result of cleaning up a toxic spill — was not delivered to the audience, but only to reporters.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20070615.RTICKERMN15/TPStory/ |title=Pranksters disrupt oil patch conference |first=Norvall |last=Scott |publisher=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=June 15, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070822190312/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20070615.RTICKERMN15/TPStory/ |archivedate=August 22, 2007 |df= }}</ref>
=== Milton Friedman documentary === In July 2007, in order to obtain interviews with right wing think tanks, the Yes Men pretended to be filming a documentary about [[Milton Friedman]]. (In fact, their documentary, ''[[The Yes Men Fix the World]]'', did end up speaking about Friedman at length.) After interviewing members of the [[Competitive Enterprise Institute]] and the [[American Enterprise Institute]], several of whom appear in the film, the Yes Men were foiled at the [[Cato Institute]] by libertarian activists [[Bureaucrash]], one of whose members had been hanging around the Competitive Enterprise Institute two days before and recognized the duo. On their way out, Bureaucrash members threw colored powder at the Yes Men in a reference to the rainbow.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pranks.com/2007/07/14/cato-institute-kos-yes-men-attempt/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023215659/http://pranks.com/2007/07/14/cato-institute-kos-yes-men-attempt/|archivedate=October 23, 2007|title=Just Say No to the Yes Men|date=July 13, 2007|first=Richard |last=Morrison}}</ref>
=== BP === On March 10, 2008, the Yes Men responded to a letter from [[BP]] (merged from British Petroleum and [[Amoco]]) accusing them of [[copyright violation]], with a letter apologizing for having forgotten BP with the spoof site half-completed and that "BP does every bit as much damage to this planet as does Exxon, [[Halliburton]], or any other more obviously nefarious company" and deserves its own properly completed spoof site.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theyesmen.org/agribusiness/beyondpetrol/|title=Apology to BP|last=Bichlbaum|first=Andy|date=March 10, 2008|publisher=The Yes Men|accessdate=June 8, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100608114230/http://theyesmen.org/agribusiness/beyondpetrol/|archivedate=June 8, 2010|df=}}</ref>
=== Captain Euro === In 1999, the Yes Men visited the offices of [[Corporate Vision Strategists|Twelve Star Communications]], creators of the [[Europhile|Eurofederalist]] superhero [[Captain Euro]], "a comic book character designed to promote European unification with young children." Inside, the impostors discover the hidden, dark truth about European Unification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theyesmen.org/hijinks/euro|title=Making Europe Fun and Interesting|year=2000|accessdate=April 22, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130324195156/http://theyesmen.org/hijinks/euro|archivedate=March 24, 2013|df=}}</ref>
=== ''New York Times'' === The Yes Men (along with the Anti-Advertising Agency) also claimed partial responsibility for a prank on November 12, 2008, where approximately 80,000 copies of a fake edition of the July 4, 2009 edition of ''[[The New York Times]]'' were handed out on the streets of New York and Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web|first=Steve |last=Lambert |url=http://fillip.ca/content/best-case-scenario |title=Fillip / Best Case Scenario |publisher=Fillip.ca |date= |accessdate=August 2, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Dobnik |first=Verena |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/books/news/2008-11-12-new-york-times_N.htm |title='New York Times' spoof circulated |work=[[USA Today]] |date=November 13, 2008 |accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref> The fake edition shows their ideas for a better future with headlines such as ''Iraq War Ends'' and ''Nation Sets Its Sights on Building Sane Economy''. The front page contained a spoofed motto, "All the News We Hope to Print" from the famous phrase "All the news that's fit to print".<ref>{{cite web|first=Ed |last=Pilkington |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/nov/12/new-york-times-spoof |title=New York Times 'special edition' spoof perplexes readers |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=November 12, 2008 |accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref> Articles in the paper announce dozens of new initiatives, including an establishment of national health care, a [[maximum wage]] for C.E.O.s and an article wherein [[George W. Bush]] accuses himself of treason for his actions during his years as president.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/media/0,4906,19346,00.pdf |title=Der Spiegel |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://nytimes-se.mayfirst.org/NYTimes-SE.pdf Spoofed NYT newspaper] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521050904/http://nytimes-se.mayfirst.org/NYTimes-SE.pdf |date=May 21, 2009 }}</ref> There is also a [[Reuters]] photo of the fake cover page<ref name="sewell">{{cite web|last=Chan |first=Sewell |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/11/12/pranksters-spoof-the-times/ |title=Liberal Pranksters Hand Out Times Spoof |publisher=The New York Times |date=November 12, 2008 |accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Nolan |first=Hamilton |url=http://gawker.com/5084164/fake-new-york-times-declares-iraq-war-over-heres-who-did-it |title=Fake New York Times Declares Iraq War Over! Here's Who Did It |publisher=Gawker |date=November 12, 2008 |accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7725973.stm |title=Pranksters print spoof NY Times |publisher=BBC News |date=November 12, 2008 |accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref> and a fake website, http://www.nytimes-se.com/.
[[Alex Jones (journalist)|Alex S. Jones]], a former ''Times'' reporter and media scholar, said of the paper, "I would say if you’ve got one, hold on to it...it will probably be a collector’s item. I’m just glad someone thinks ''The New York Times'' print edition is worthy of an elaborate hoax. A Web spoof would have been infinitely easier. But creating a print newspaper and handing it out at subway stations? That takes a lot of effort."<ref name="sewell"/>
=== ''New York Post'' and SurvivaBall === On September 21, 2009, one day before a UN summit lead-up to the [[United Nations Climate Change Conference 2009]], over 2,000 volunteers distributed throughout New York City a 32-page "special edition" ''[[New York Post]]'', blaring headlines (cover story "We're Screwed") that the city could face deadly heat waves, extreme flooding, and other lethal effects of global warming within the next few decades. The paper had been created by the Yes Men and a coalition of activists as a wake-up call to action on climate change. Other articles describe the Pentagon's alarmed response to [[global warming]], the U.S. government's minuscule response, China's advanced alternative energy program, and how the [[COP15]] in Copenhagen could be a "Flopenhagen".<ref>[http://vimeo.com/6676567 "SPECIAL EDITION" NEW YORK POST] by the Yes Men</ref> There is also a fake website.<ref>http://nypost-se.com/ "WE'RE SCREWED" climate change special edition New York Post online edition September 21, 2009</ref> A "climate change horoscope" satire on the Sally Brompton horoscope in the Post was commissioned from an environmental activist horoscope writer but was not published.
On September 22, 2009 the Yes Men demonstrated on the alleged behalf of [[Halliburton]] and dozens of other climate threatening corporations an inflatable ball-shaped costume known as the SurvivaBall, claiming it was a self-contained living system for surviving disasters caused by global warming. Over two dozen people wore the SurvivaBall costumes as it was demonstrated in the East River.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.babelgum.com/4005324/balls-across-america.html |title=Balls Across America |publisher=Babelgum.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811210656/http://www.babelgum.com/4005324/balls-across-america.html |archivedate=2010-08-11 |df= }}</ref> Police shut down the demonstration for lack of a permit. Co-founder of the Yes Men, Andy Bichlbaum, was arrested on an outstanding parking ticket charge and a handful of other Yes Men were served with summons and tickets for disorderly behavior and creating hazardous conditions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Fake-Post-Guys-Pull-Another-One-Yes-Man-Arrested-60700217.html |title=Cops Arrest "Yes Men" Co-Founder in Latest Prank |publisher=[[NBC]] |first=Jennifer |last=Millman |date=September 24, 2009 |accessdate=April 18, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indypendent.org/2009/09/22/yes-men-arrest/ |title=The Yes Men’s Andy Bichlbaum Arrested at ‘SurvivaBall’ Demo |publisher=[[The Indypendent]] |first=Jaisal |last=Noor |date=September 22, 2009 |accessdate=April 18, 2011}}</ref>
The SurvivaBall was also used in a protest at the steps of the capitol. The protesting balls demanded action be taken on global warming to achieve the [[350.org]] goal. Their strategy was to block the entrance until the government comes to a binding agreement on climate change.<ref>[http://theyesmen.org/hijinks/survivaball Survivaball] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130324234513/http://theyesmen.org/hijinks/survivaball |date=2013-03-24 }} from TheYesMen.org, retrieved 12 May 2015</ref>
=== US Chamber of Commerce === On October 19, 2009, the Yes Men spoofed the [[United States Chamber of Commerce]], declaring a U-turn on their climate change policy.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2009/oct/19/chamber-commerce-climate-hoax|title=US Chamber of Commerce falls victim to 'fraud' over climate hoax|last=Goldenberg|first=Suzanne |date=19 October 2009|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-10-20 | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vYGcIhNGSIY |title=Will the real chamber of Commerce please stand up? |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=October 19, 2009 |accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref> The Yes Men were not able to complete the conference without being exposed as a hoax, although their message that the United States Chamber of Commerce needs to reevaluate their direction in terms of clean energy was their primary concern and was received. Major TV and news organisations carried this story briefly before the hoax was uncovered. The US Chamber of Commerce two weeks later did change their official policy though, according to [[Al Gore]] it was "not because of" the Yes Men's stunt. The Chamber launched a trademark and copyright infringement lawsuit against The Yes Men, who were defended by the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]]. The suit was dropped in June 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://grist.org/news/yes-men-prank-the-chamber-of-commerce-and-get-away-with-it | publisher=Grist | title=Yes Men prank the Chamber of Commerce — and get away with it|last=Upton|first=John|date=June 14, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/202401/chamber-of-commerce-drops-lawsuit-against-parodist.html |publisher=Online Media Daily| title=Chamber Of Commerce Drops Lawsuit Against Parodists|last=Davis|first=Wendy|date=June 14, 2013}}</ref>
This action appears in their film, ''The Yes Men Are Revolting''.
=== Canadian environment minister === During the [[2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] in [[Copenhagen]], the Yes Men put out a statement in which they purported to be the Canadian environment minister, [[Jim Prentice]]. The statement pledged to cut carbon emissions by 40% below 1990 levels by 2020. The statement was followed by a response from the Ugandan delegation, praising the statement, that was also faked. Another fake statement was then put out blasting the falsehoods of the original fake statement. A fake story in a European edition of the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' was also posted online. Jim Prentice described the hoax as "undesirable".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2009/dec/14/environment-canada-spoof|title=Copenhagen spoof shames Canada on the truth about its emissions|last=Goldenberg|first=Suzanne |date=December 14, 2009 |publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=December 14, 2009 | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.babelgum.com/4021000/yes-men-canada-takes-stand-climate-change-not.html|title=Yes Men: Canada Takes Stand on Climate Change. NOT!|publisher=[[Babelgum]]|date=|accessdate=August 2, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811205255/http://www.babelgum.com/4021000/yes-men-canada-takes-stand-climate-change-not.html|archivedate=August 11, 2010|df=}}</ref>
=== Niger Delta Hoax === On March 28, 2010, a video was released on [[YouTube]] with the title "Shell: We are sorry".<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zciWUOrIUqo|title=Shell: We are sorry|date=28 March 2010|work=YouTube}}</ref> A man called Bradford Houppe, from the Ethical Affairs Committee at [[Royal Dutch Shell]] gave a four-minute-long apology to the people of the [[Niger Delta]] for ruining their land, water, and communities. This video was created in response to the numerous environmental problems and human rights violations that have occurred in the Niger Delta region of [[Nigeria]] since Shell began oil exploration in the region decades ago. Shell has yet to make any official statement about this video.
=== GE Tax Refund Hoax reported by the AP ===
On April 13, 2011, a hoax website with a [[URL]] similar to that of the [[GE]] press domain (genewscenter.com) designed to look like the GE news center website. The hoax site posted the claim "GE Responds to Public Outcry – Will Donate Entire $3.2 Billion Tax Refund to Help Offset Cuts and Save American Jobs." and it seems that the [[Associated Press|AP]] reported the story as fact, as reported by [[Good (magazine)|''Good'']].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.good.is/post/ap-falls-for-hoax-that-ge-will-donate-3-billion-tax-refund/ |title=AP Falls for Hoax that GE Will Donate $3 Billion Tax Refund |publisher=Good.is |first=Alex |last=Goldmark |date=April 13, 2011 |accessdate=April 18, 2011}}</ref>
=== Shell Oil and ArcticReady.com ===
In June 2012, the Yes Men collaborated with [[Greenpeace]] and members of the [[Occupy Seattle]] movement to create ArcticReady.com, a parody website criticizing Shell Oil's drilling activities in the arctic circle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greenpeace.org/new-zealand/en/blog/shellfail-inside-story-greenpeace-yes-men/blog/40876/ |title=Greenpeace, the Yes Men and the inside story of #ShellFail}}</ref> The website launch was commemorated by a fake launch party held in the [[Seattle Space Needle]]. Shell Oil disavowed any affiliation with the website or the launch party on June 14, 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.shell.us/home/content/usa/aboutshell/projects_locations/alaska/events_news/06142012_statement.html |title = Shell not involved in spoof video and fake advertisements |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120729020118/http://www.shell.us/home/content/usa/aboutshell/projects_locations/alaska/events_news/06142012_statement.html |archivedate = 2012-07-29 |df = }}</ref>
=== The Action Switchboard ===
The Action Switchboard is a platform the Yes Men launched to link up people who want to be involved in activism events with people organising them. As it says<ref>{{cite web|url=https://actionswitchboard.net/about-action-switchboard|title=About the Action Switchboard|work=Action Switchboard}}</ref> "The Action Switchboard is a platform that helps activists find each other, come up with direct action ideas, and get the resources they need to pull them off."
=== VW/Dieselgate apology === In November 2018, Motherboard/Vice released a video about The Yes Men and their fake VW "Emissions Anonymous" project. In the prank, they apologize to the public for the [[Volkswagen emissions scandal|Dieselgate emissions scandal]], in which several models and years of VW car family diesel autos were engineered and built with a rigged emissions system that ran clean only while under test conditions, but otherwise released high levels of air pollutants.<ref>{{Citation|last=Motherboard|title=Faking Volkswagen's Dieselgate Apology with the Yes Men|date=2018-11-19|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fI-7631xaJQ|access-date=2018-11-29}}</ref> The Houston Chronicle even covered the pranksters' April 2018 entry in Houston's annual [[Houston Art Car Parade|Art Car Parade]] as if an official VW PR campaign: "The marketing department has even turned the crisis into a publicity shtick".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/columnists/tomlinson/article/Response-to-VW-diesel-emissions-scandal-will-12888576.php|title=Response to VW diesel emissions scandal will define former CEO|date=2018-05-07|work=HoustonChronicle.com|access-date=2018-11-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
